{{Infobox university | name = Duke Kunshan University
昆山杜克大学 | image = DKU_Logo_whitebackdrop.jpg | established = 2013{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/01/02/duke-kunshan-university_n_2397356.html|title=Duke Kunshan University, China Campus, Marks Government Approval, Announces Next Steps|first=William|last=McGuinness|date=2 January 2013|publisher=|accessdate=21 September 2017|via=Huff Post}} | type = Private | chancellor = [[Youmei Feng]] | dean = Marcia France | city = Kunshan | campus = [[Suburban]]/[[Urban area|Urban]], 200 acres (0.81 km2) | website = [https://dukekunshan.edu.cn/ dukekunshan.edu.cn] | location = [[Kunshan]], [[Jiangsu]], [[China]] | affiliations = [[Alliance of Asian Liberal Arts Universities|AALAU]], [[Duke University]], [[Wuhan University]] | head_label = [[Chancellor (education)#Vice-chancellor|Executive Vice Chancellor]] | head = Denis Simon | students = 266 (Fall 2018) }} '''Duke Kunshan University''' '''(DKU)''' is a Chinese-American partnership of [[Duke University]] ([[Durham, North Carolina]], [[United States]]) and [[Wuhan University]] ([[Wuhan]], [[Hubei]], [[China]]) to create a liberal arts and research university offering academic programs for students from China and throughout the world.{{Cite web|url=https://dukekunshan.edu.cn/en/about/duke-kunshan|title=About Duke Kunshan University|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} DKU received approval from the [[Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China|Chinese Ministry of Education]] in 2013 and its curricula are also approved by the Jiangsu Provincial Education Bureau. Students have the opportunity to study at both the DKU campus in [[Kunshan]], China and at Duke University in [[Durham, North Carolina|Durham]], United States. Undergraduate students will have the opportunity to spend a summer and a semester on the Duke University campus in Durham, North Carolina. Students are awarded degrees from both Duke University and Duke Kunshan University upon graduation and become members of both institutions’ alumni organizations.{{Cite web|url=http://undergrad.dukekunshan.edu.cn/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/Fact-sheet-September-20180908.pdf|title=Duke Kunshan University Fact Sheet|last=|first=|date=|website=http://undergrad.dukekunshan.edu.cn|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Both Duke University and Wuhan University have been recognized in the top ten in respective national rankings.{{Cite news|url=https://today.duke.edu/2011/09/usnews2011|title=Duke In Top 10 of Latest U.S. News Rankings|access-date=2018-06-26|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.cuaa.net/cur/2016/|title=2016中国大学排行榜700强,北京大学雄居榜首 艾瑞深中国校友会网(cuaa.net) -2016中国大学排行榜,2016中国独立学院排行榜,2016中国民办大学排行榜|website=www.cuaa.net|language=en|access-date=2018-06-26}} The universities collaborate on academic programs and administration for Duke Kunshan University, while the city of Kunshan agreed to lease land for the DKU campus at no cost for 10 years and funded the construction of the US$200 million campus buildings. == History and Timeline == * Jan. 2010 - A Cooperation Agreement signed between Duke University and the People's Government of Kunshan{{Cite web|url=https://dukekunshan.edu.cn/en/about/dku-milestones|title=Milestones of Duke Kunshan University {{!}} Duke Kunshan University|website=dukekunshan.edu.cn|language=en|access-date=2018-11-19}} * Sep. 2010 - Construction of Duke Kunshan Phase 1 campus started * Jan. 2011 - Cooperation Principles Statement signed between Duke University and Wuhan University * Jun. 2011 - Application for Preparation Approval of Duke Kunshan University submitted to Jiangsu Provincial Bureau of Education * Aug. 2012 - Preparation Approval from the [[Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China|Chinese Ministry of Education]] * Sep. 2012 - Appointments of Duke Kunshan Chancellor and Executive Vice Chancellor * Dec. 2012 - Celebration Ceremony of Preparation Approval in Kunshan * Apr. 2013 - Application for formal establishment of Duke Kunshan University submitted to [[Jiangsu]] Provincial Bureau of Education * Sep. 2013 - Duke Kunshan Establishment Approval granted by the Chinese Ministry of Education * Nov. 2013 - First meeting of Duke Kunshan Board of Trustees held at Wuhan University * Dec. 2013 - Duke Kunshan legal entity registration completed * Jan. 2014 - Duke Kunshan Advisory Board established * Apr. 2014 - Second Meeting of Duke Kunshan Board of Trustees held in Kunshan * May 2014 - First meeting of Duke Kunshan Advisory Board held in Beijing * Jul. 2014 - Duke Kunshan [[Masters in Management Studies|MMS]] program began in [[Durham, North Carolina|Durham]] * Aug. 2014 - Inaugural Convocation and Orientation Week held at Duke Kunshan University * Aug. 2018 - Inaugural Undergraduate Program begins{{Cite web|url=https://dukekunshan.edu.cn/en/news/arrival-class-of-2022|title=DUKE KUNSHAN UNIVERSITY WELCOMES ITS FIRST UNDERGRADUATE CLASS {{!}} Duke Kunshan University|website=dukekunshan.edu.cn|language=en|access-date=2018-11-19}} == Administration and organization == Duke Kunshan University is governed by an independent Board of Trustees.{{Cite web|url=https://dukekunshan.edu.cn/en/about/duke-kunshan|title=About Duke Kunshan|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} [[Liu Jingnan]], the university's first chancellor and a member of the Chinese Academy of Engineering, stepped down in August 2018. {{Cite news|url=https://today.duke.edu/2018/08/feng-youmei-named-new-chancellor-duke-kunshan-university|title=Feng Youmei Named New Chancellor Of Duke Kunshan University|access-date=2018-11-07|language=en}} Youmei Feng, the current Chancellor, is the former executive vice president of Wuhan University and is one of a few female university chancellors in China. Denis Simon, Executive Vice Chancellor, is an expert on U.S.-China bilateral science and technology relations and a member of the U.S. Experts Group within the U.S.-China Innovation Dialogue. Haiyan Gao, Vice Chancellor for Academic Affairs at Duke Kunshan University, is also the Henry Newson professor of physics at Duke University. Marcia France was appointed Dean of Undergraduate Studies in June 2018. France was previously the associate provost at [[Washington and Lee University]] in [[Lexington, Virginia]], USA. == Academics == === Undergraduate admissions === Duke Kunshan University admitted its first undergraduate students as part of the Class of 2022. Significantly exceeding its original target of 1,500 applicants, the university received a total of 3,143 applications for an estimated 225 first-year spots, including 2,551 applications from China and 332 from the United States. There were 80 countries represented in the applicant pool, including Kazakhstan, South Korea, Pakistan, and Ethiopia.{{Cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com/news/local/counties/durham-county/article200601389.html|title=Applicants for slots at its Kunshan, China campus swamping Duke projections. See why.|work=heraldsun|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en}} In March 2018, DKU admitted 251 students, or 7.98% of its inaugural applicant pool, a selectivity similar to the 8.3% acceptance rate at Duke University.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dukechronicle.com/article/2018/04/duke-kunshan-university-accepts-250-students-to-its-class-of-2022|title=Duke Kunshan University accepts 250 students to its class of 2022|work=The Chronicle|access-date=2018-06-25}} Chinese students applying to DKU are required to take the [[National Higher Education Entrance Examination|Gaokao]], the national college entrance exam of the People's Republic of China. The Gaokao enables students to list Duke Kunshan University as one of their college choices. International students, including those from the United States, submit transcripts, [[SAT]] or [[ACT (test)|ACT]] standardized test scores, and application essays. Duke Kunshan University has planned to expand each undergraduate class to 500 students, for a total of 2,000 undergraduates. === Academic programs === Duke Kunshan University has signed legally binding agreements with [[Education Ministry of China]] that guaranteed academic freedom on campus.{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/09ecaae2-ccd0-11e7-b781-794ce08b24dc|title=Beijing vies for greater control of foreign universities in China|date=2017-11-19|website=Financial Times}} [[File:Duke Kunshan University Academic Building Interior.jpg|thumb|398x398px|Interior of the DKU Academic Building]] The university began enrolling graduate students in 2014. It offers [[Master's degree|Master's]] programs in Medical Physics, Global Health, Environmental Policy, Management Studies and Electrical and Computer Engineering. In 2018, DKU began enrolling undergraduate students for the Class of 2022, with an initial class size of roughly 225 students. Each undergraduate major consists of an interdisciplinary set of courses that integrate different forms of knowledge and a distinct set of disciplinary courses that provide expertise in specific areas. Current undergraduate programs include:{{Cite news|url=http://undergrad.dukekunshan.edu.cn/majors/|title=Majors - Duke Kunshan University|work=Duke Kunshan University|access-date=2018-11-18|language=en-US}} '''Natural Sciences''' * Material Science/Physics * Environmental Science/Chemistry * Global Health/Biology * Applied Mathematics and Computational Sciences/Math * Data Science *Molecular Bioscience (with tracks) **Cell and Molecular Biology **Biogeochemistry **Genetics and Genomics **Biophysics '''Social Sciences''' * Political Economy/Political Science * Institutions and Governance/Economics * Cultures and Movements (with tracks) ** Sociology ** Cultural Anthropology * Global Health/Public Policy * Environmental Science/Public Policy '''Arts and Humanities''' * US Studies (with tracks) ** History ** Literature * Ethics and Leadership (with tracks) ** Philosophy ** Religious Studies * Global China Studies/History * Global Cultural Studies/Literature * Media and Arts (with tracks) ** Creative Practice ** History Each major consists of an interdisciplinary set of courses that integrates different forms of knowledge and a distinct set of disciplinary courses that provides expertise in specific areas. International students will take Chinese language for the first two years and can continue with more advanced courses afterwards. Current graduate programs include: * Master of Environmental Policy *Master of Science in Medical Physics *Master of Science in Global Health *Master of Management Studies *Master of Electrical and Computer Engineering In 2017, Duke Kunshan University selected PeopleSoft's Campus Solutions to manage its student records and transactions and Oracle Student Cloud to support student recruitment, enrollment and engagement.{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/duke-kunshan-university-selects-oracle-to-optimize-student-experience-300488568.html|title=Duke Kunshan University Selects Oracle to Optimize Student Experience|first=|last=Oracle|website=www.prnewswire.com|accessdate=21 September 2017}} == Campus == [[File:Suzhou Kunshan - Lianshubang IMG 8871.jpg|thumb|Panorama of the central business district of Kunshan, Jiangsu, China|alt=|318x318px]] Duke Kunshan is located in a 200-acre campus in [[Kunshan]], a city in [[Jiangsu province]]. The campus is to become the center of the Duke Creative Park, part of the city's “Five Zones, One Line” plan for urban renewal. The area will host the Sino-US (Kunshan) Technology Innovation Center and serve as a mixed-used project integrating R&D centers, business services, and ecological parks.{{Cite news|url=http://en.savills.com.cn/_news/article/37198/168900-0/9/2018/kunshan-releases-%E2%80%9Cfive-zones--one-line%E2%80%9D-plan-for-urban-renewal|title=Kunshan releases “Five Zones, One Line” plan for urban renewal|access-date=2018-11-17}} Adjacent to campus is the Dayu Bay Commercial Street, which features a [[Starbucks]], a dozen restaurants, convenience store, social hall, clothing and sporting good shops, and a [[Duke Blue Devils|Duke]]-themed sports bar.{{Cite news|url=https://today.duke.edu/2018/08/students-around-world-move-duke-kunshan-university|title=Students From Around the World Move in at Duke Kunshan University|access-date=2018-11-19|language=en}} Kunshan's location between [[Shanghai]] and [[Suzhou]] allows easy access to these major metropolitan centers by highways and high-speed railway. {{Cite web|url=https://global.duke.edu/duke-kunshan-university-virtual-tour|title=A Duke Kunshan University Virtual Tour|last=|first=|date=|website=Duke Global|archive-url=|archive-date=July 7, 2016|dead-url=|access-date=}} The campus blends traditional [[Chinese architecture|Chinese]] elements with advanced educational technology in a spacious, modern setting. Extensive aquatic elements, including an aquatic quadrangle at the center of campus, symbolize the region's famous water towns and are integrated throughout the campus, while information technology and Telepresence systems provide connections to colleagues and classmates around the world. The site has a high water table, so designers elected to preserve 40 acres as [[Community gardening|community gardens]].{{Cite web|url=https://dukekunshan.edu.cn/en/campus|title=The Campus of Duke Kunshan University in China{{!}}Medical Physics{{!}}Global Health{{!}}Health Physics{{!}}DKU, dku.edu.cn|website=dukekunshan.edu.cn|language=en|access-date=2018-11-19}}[[File:Duke Kunshan University Campus Panorama.jpg|thumb|456x456px|Panorama of Phase I of Duke Kunshan University's Water Feature, which separates the Academic Building (L), Conference Center (R) and Innovation Center (Background).]]The campus is being constructed in phases, with Phase I designed by American design and architecture firm [[Gensler]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.gensler.com/projects/duke-kunshan-university|title=Duke Kunshan University {{!}} Projects {{!}} Gensler|website=Gensler|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-17}} Phase 1 facilities include an academic building with a variety of classroom configurations, a 200-bed dormitory building, a conference center and hotel, a faculty residence, and an administration building. An innovation center equipped with a library, classrooms and team rooms will open in 2019. Phase 2 is scheduled for completion in 2021,{{Cite news|url=https://www.dukechronicle.com/article/2017/04/dku-prepares-for-launch-of-undergraduate-degree-program|title=DKU prepares for launch of undergraduate degree program|work=The Chronicle|access-date=2018-11-17}} designed by [[Perkins and Will]],{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/ProfJohnJi/status/985316361143496704|title=John Ji on Twitter|work=Twitter|access-date=2018-11-17|language=en}} and will feature an expansion of undergraduate, graduate, and faculty housing, a community center, recreation center, the WD Research Institute, and a library.{{Citation|last=Duke Kunshan|title=A Campus for the Future|date=2018-05-06|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Evg7kTIPONY|access-date=2018-11-17}} Later plans call for Phase III and IV construction to take place in the coming decade. The Duke Kunshan University project is expected to last at least 50-100 years. As part of the partnership between Duke University, [[Wuhan University]], and the city of Kunshan, the municipal government has leased the Duke Kunshan University campus to the university at no cost for the first ten years as well as paying for construction of the buildings.{{Cite news|url=https://www.chronicle.com/article/Dukes-China-Plan-Sparks/127640|title=Duke's China Plan Sparks Doubts on Campus|date=2011-05-25|work=The Chronicle of Higher Education|access-date=2018-06-26}} == Campus Life == [[File:Duke Kunshan University Undergraduate and Faculty Housing.jpg|thumb|288x288px|Student and Faculty Housing on the Duke Kunshan University Campus]] '''Clubs & Organizations'''{{Cite web|url=https://dukekunshan.edu.cn/en/student-life/clubs-organizations|title=Clubs & Organizations {{!}} Duke Kunshan University|website=dukekunshan.edu.cn|language=en|access-date=2018-11-19}} * Kunshan Student Ambassador Council (KSAC) * Documentary&Arts (Doc&Arts) * International Association * Kun Opera Club * Student Volunteer Association == Research centers == [[File:Duke Kunshan University Academic Building.jpg|thumb|384x384px|Duke Kunshan University Campus Academic Building]] * Global Health Research Center (1st research center at Duke Kunshan){{cite web |url=https://dukekunshan.edu.cn/en/global-health/global-health-research-center}} * Regional Ozone Sino-US Collaborative Research Center * WHU-DUKE Research Institute at Duke Kunshan * Center for the Study of Contemporary China * Humanities Research Center * Environmental Research Center{{cite web|url=https://dukekunshan.edu.cn/en/environment|title=Duke Kunshan Environment|first=|last=hermes|date=20 September 2018|publisher=|accessdate=20 September 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/china-punishes-18000-companies-for-pollution|title=China punishes 18,000 companies for pollution|first=|last=hermes|date=3 September 2017|publisher=|accessdate=21 September 2017}} The Global Health Research Center (GHRC), founded in 2013, is the first research center at Duke Kunshan University. The GHRC uses innovative approaches to research and solve important health and health policy challenges in China and around the world. The GHRC is built on the principles of scientific excellence and focuses on establishing interdisciplinary, mutually-beneficial collaborations with researchers from China. It will host national and international conferences to disseminate research findings and encourage dialogue among scientists, professionals, policy-makers and other key stakeholders engaged in global health. The GHRC focuses on four research areas: emerging infectious diseases, environmental health, health policy and systems, and non-communicable chronic diseases. Between 2013-2018, researchers at the GHRC have published over 160 peer-reviewed papers in a variety of journals including the Lancet, Lancet Global Health, JAMA, JAMA Internal Medicine, Circulation, PLOS Medicine, American Journal of Public Health, and American Journal of Epidemiology. The faculty and research activities complement the global health education programs offered at Duke Kunshan University, including the Master of Science in Global Health and the undergraduate semester courses in global health. The Environmental Research Center draws knowledge from an array of fields together to tackle the most pressing environmental challenges in China, Asia and the world. Experts and scholars cooperate and inspire each other over the discussion and research on topics such as energy, climate change, water, ecosystem conservation, environment and public health. The center has become a platform where policy problems come for solutions and where knowledge and talents serve the society. == Conferences == *'''International Meteorite Conference, Meteorite China''' - Duke Kunshan University hosted China's first-ever international meteorite conference on 15 September 2017. Over 80 scientists from China, the U.S., the U.K., Australia, and Russia met at the three-day event. Enthusiasts and meteorite collectors also participated in the conference.{{cite web|url=http://www.sixthtone.com/news/1000866/scientists-and-meteorite-hunters-descend-on-suzhou|title=Scientists and Meteorite Hunters Descend on Suzhou|first=Sixth|last=Tone|publisher=|accessdate=21 September 2017}} == See also == *[[Duke University]] *[[Wuhan University]] *[[NYU Shanghai]] *[[New York University Abu Dhabi|NYU Abu Dhabi]] *[[Yale-NUS College]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://dukekunshan.edu.cn/ Official website] {{en icon}} *[https://dukekunshan.edu.cn/zh Official website] {{zh icon}} {{Duke University}} {{Wuhan University}} {{Alliance of Asian Liberal Arts Universities}} {{Coord|31|25|3.67|N|120|53|35.96|E|display=inline,title}} [[Category:Wuhan University]] [[Category:Duke University]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Suzhou]] [[Category:Kunshan]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 2013]] [[Category:2013 establishments in China]] [[Category:Duke family]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2017}} {{Use British English|date=February 2017}} {{Multiple issues| {{advert|date=September 2014}} {{notability|date=September 2014}} }}
The '''Gatwick Diamond''' is a name invented as a brand for a loosely defined economic area that surrounds Gatwick Airport, some 30 miles south of London.
== Scope == The area stretches from the edge of London and the North Downs in the north to the edge of Brighton and the South Downs in the south, and from Horsham in the west to East Grinstead in the east. It benefits from two Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty: the [[Surrey Hills AONB|Surrey Hills]] and the [[South Downs National Park]]. It has an area of some 400 square miles and a population of 680,000; its economy generates £20.7bn GDP. 12 million people live within one hour's drive. There are 406,000 economically active people in the Gatwick Diamond; 81% of the working age population is economically active. 74% of Gatwick Diamond workers are residents (annual population survey 2011). The unemployment level is very low at 1.4%. The Gatwick Diamond is home to 45,000 businesses including many UK and European Headquarters. Some of these companies are: [[Unilever]], [[Exxon Mobil]], [[Toyota]], [[Doosan]], [[Thales Group]], [[Varian Medical Systems]], [[Elekta]], [[Nestle]], [[EDF Energy]], Edwards Vacuum, [[Canon Inc.]] and [[G4S]]. It also contains the Manor Royal Business Park – the largest business park in the UK,<ref name="manorroyal">[http://www.manorroyal.org/pages/index.cfm Manor Royal Homepage]</ref> housing 550 businesses and employing around 35,000 people.
== Initiative ==
The Gatwick Diamond Initiative is a business-led private/public partnership that was established in April 2003 to improve the economic performance of the area.<ref name="gdi">[http://www.gatwickdiamond.co.uk/ Gatwick Diamond Initiative]</ref> It now includes seven local borough/district councils ([[Horsham District|Horsham]], [[Crawley]], [[Mid Sussex]], [[Tandridge District|Tandridge]], [[Reigate & Banstead]], [[Mole Valley]] and [[Epsom & Ewell]]) and two county councils ([[West Sussex]] and [[Surrey]]), as well as a range of private sector partners.
One of its first actions was to arrange a meeting of the principal stakeholders (both public and private sector) to determine what actions could be taken to improve the economic performance of the area. Business leaders considered that the first priority should be to give the area an image and identity. The Initiative therefore launched the "Gatwick Diamond" on 15 July 2004. Since then the term "Gatwick Diamond" has achieved widespread recognition and acceptance. It was first referred to in parliament by [[Nicholas Soames]], MP for Mid Sussex, on 13 Jun 2006.<ref>Hansard https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200506/cmhansrd/vo060613/halltext/60613h0002.htm</ref> The Gatwick Diamond Initiative lobbies government and the public sector on issues that prevent businesses in the area from growing; they encourage international trade; promote, attract and help UK and foreign inward investors looking to locate in the area; campaign on issues such as Air Passenger Duty, Gatwick's second runway and the [[Gatwick Express]]; and encourage the three Further Education colleges at Redhill, Crawley and Epsom to work together with the [[University of Brighton]] and [[University for the Creative Arts]] to provide Higher and Further Education to meet business needs.
== Economy == {{Unreferenced section|date=September 2017}} The Gatwick Diamond area is situated directly south of London and covers the east of Surrey and northwest of Sussex. The heart of the area is 30 miles from Central London. By rail, the Gatwick Express can get to Central London in 30 minutes. Gatwick Airport is situated at the centre of the Gatwick Diamond and is a nominal 1 hour's drive from Heathrow Airport, subject to frequent delays on the M25. The Gatwick Diamond is within 1 hour from the sea ports of Shoreham and Newhaven and 90 minutes from Dover, Southampton and Portsmouth sea ports. By road, the M23 bisects the Gatwick Diamond and is just 10 minutes from the M25. By bus, the Metrobus Fastway service takes many employees in the Gatwick Diamond to their workplace; coaches leave Gatwick to reach 400 UK towns and cities. The Gatwick Diamond is an economic area worth £20.7bn GDP (growing at 3% per year), with a population of 680,000.
== Gatwick Airport ==
[[Gatwick Airport]] has 48 airlines which fly to 200 destinations, more than any other UK airport. The airport connects to 45 out of 50 top European destinations and over half of the world’s emerging markets. In 2014, the airport had 38.6 million passengers pass through it. This contributes towards Gatwick being the busiest single-runway airport in the world. The airport's railway station was used by 18 million passengers in 2015-16,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://orr.gov.uk/statistics/published-stats/station-usage-estimates|title=Estimates of station usage|last=|first=|date=|website=[[Office of Rail and Road]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=25 September 2017}}</ref> making it the busiest airport station in the UK.
== The Gatwick Diamond Business Association ==
The Gatwick Diamond Business Association (until 2012, the Crawley and District Industry Association) offers networking opportunities at its monthly members' meetings. It operates like the other membership organisations in the area such as the Chambers of Commerce, Sussex Enterprise and Surrey Chambers of Commerce and the Federation of Small Businesses, but concentrates on the Gatwick Diamond area. It also delivers the Gatwick Diamond Business Awards.
== Member organisations == * [http://www.gatwickdiamondbusiness.com/ Gatwick Diamond Business Association] * [http://www.sussexenterprise.co.uk/ Sussex Chamber of Commerce] * [http://www.surrey-chambers.co.uk/ Surrey Chambers of Commerce] * [http://www.crawleychamber.co.uk/ Crawley & Gatwick Chamber of Commerce] * [http://www.manorroyal.org/pages/index.cfm Manor Royal Business District Association] * [http://www.eebp.co.uk/ Epsom & Ewell Business Partnership] * [http://www.leatherheadchamber.co.uk/ Leatherhead & District Chamber of Commerce] * [http://www.dorkingchamber.co.uk/ Dorking Chamber of Commerce] * [http://www.horshamchamberofcommerce.com/ Horsham Chambers of Commerce] * [http://www.bhbpa.co.uk/ Burgess Hill Business Parks Association] * [http://hhdba.com/home/ Haywards heath & District Business Association] * [http://www.reigatebusinessguild.co.uk/ Reigate Business Guild] * [http://www.horleychamberofcommerce.co.uk/ Horley & District Chamber of Commerce]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.gatwickdiamond.co.uk/}}

{{Infobox person | name = Hans-Holger Albrecht | image = | caption = Hans-Holger Albrecht | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1963|7|29|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]] | occupation = [[CEO]], [[Deezer]] | parents = [[Ernst Albrecht (politician)|Ernst Albrecht]]
Heidi Adele Albrecht }} '''Hans-Holger Albrecht''' (born 1963) is a German businessman. He is CEO of [[Deezer]], one of the largest music streaming services worldwide. Deezer offers more than 35 million tracks in over 180 countries to currently more than 16 million active monthly users. He is the brother of [[Ursula von der Leyen]], German Federal Minister of Defence. == Early life == Hans-Holger was born in Brussels, Belgium, in 1963 to Heidi Adele and [[Ernst Albrecht (politician)|Ernst (Carl Julius) Albrecht]], a prominent [[Christian Democratic Union (Germany)|CDU]] politician and [[European Commission]] official. In 1971, the family moved to Germany, where Ernst Albrecht became Premier of [[Lower Saxony]] (1976–1990). He grew up in [[Burgdorf, Hanover|Burgdorf]] in Germany. He graduated in Law at the [[University of Freiburg]] in Germany, studied at [[Yale University]], and received a PhD at the [[University of Bochum]] in Germany. He is a descendant of Baron [[Ludwig Knoop]], a cotton merchant of the city-state [[Bremen (state)|Free Hanseatic City of Bremen]] and one of the most successful entrepreneurs of the 19th century.{{cite web|url=http://www.bild.de/BILD/regional/bremen/aktuell/2009/09/19/knoop-mausoleum/fuer-90000-euro-restauriert.html |title=Der denkmalgeschützte Bau drohte zu verfallen: Altes Knoop-Mausoleum für 90000 Euro restauriert|language=de |publisher=Bild|accessdate=1 December 2011}} == Business career == Hans-Holger worked for [[Daimler-Benz]] in 1990 and for the [[Luxembourg]]-based media group CLT forerunner of [[RTL Group]].[http://www.rtlgroup.com/www/htm/operationsothers_E80A749F1ECA4B1B932D0DA748F31E0C.aspx RTL Group] from 1991 to 1996. At CLT, he was responsible for all television activities and for business development in Germany and Eastern Europe. He worked on new projects for [[RTL II|RTL2]] in Germany, [[RTL 7 (Poland)]], [[RTL Klub]] in [[Hungary]], and [[Channel 5 (UK)]], in the UK. He was also responsible for the launch of the [[Super RTL]] channel in Germany and for the development of CLT's digital TV project, [[Club RTL]] .[http://www.rtlgroup.com/www/htm/home.aspx Club RTL] He started his career at Modern Times Group MTG AB in 1997 as Head of the pay-TV operations at Viasat Broadcasting.[http://www.viasat.se Viasat Broadcasting] In 1999, he was appointed as Head of all of Viasat Broadcasting's operations. In April 2000, he was appointed Chief Operating Officer (COO) of MTG. He became President and CEO of MTG AB on 1 October 2000, when the Kinnevik Group was chaired by the late entrepreneur Jan Stenbeck, founder of MTG and telecommunications operators Tele2[http://www.tele2.com Tele2] and Millicom.[http://www.millicom.com Millicom] During his tenure, MTG's sales more than doubled from 5.4 billion Swedish krona in 2000 to 13.5 billion krona in 2011. MTG now has free-TV operations in 11 countries[http://www.mtg.se/en/brands--operations/footprint/ MTG coverage] and satellite pay-TV platforms in 9 countries, operates the Viaplay Nordic online pay-TV service[http://www.viaplay.se Viaplay] and its portfolio of 20 thematic movie, sports and documentary pay-TV channels are available in 34 countries across Europe, Russia, the CIS, Africa and the US. In November 2012, Hans-Holger became President and CEO of Millicom, an international telecommunications and media company. During his time at Millicom he transformed the company into a Digital Lifestyle company developing several new digital products and services. He became the CEO of [[Deezer]] in 2015.[http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/deezer-appoints-hans-holger-albrecht-as-chief-executive-officer-of-its-global-operations-300011872.html] == Private life == Hans-Holger Albrecht resides in London, Austria and Stockholm, and is married with seven children, as many as his sister [[Ursula von der Leyen]], who became Germany's first female defence minister on 17 December 2013. Previously she was appointed Federal Minister of Labour and Social Affairs on 30 November 2009 and, prior to that, Federal Minister of Family Affairs, Senior Citizens, Women and Youth from 2005.{{cite web|url=http://www.bild.de/BILD/regional/bremen/aktuell/2009/09/19/knoop-mausoleum/fuer-90000-euro-restauriert.html |title= Ursula von der Leyen|accessdate=1 July 2015}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * [http://www.millicom.com Millicom International Cellular SA] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Albrecht, Hans-Holger}} [[Category:German businesspeople]] [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:University of Freiburg alumni]] [[Category:Ruhr University Bochum alumni]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=July 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Like resume|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Herman Hui | image = | image_size = | caption = Hui Chung-shing (許宗盛) | birth_date = 1951 | birth_place = Hong Kong | occupation = Chairman of the [[World Scout Committee]] | signature = HermanHuiSignature.jpg }}
'''Hui Chung-shing''' ([[Chinese language|Chinese:]] 許宗盛), [[Bronze Bauhinia Star|BBS]], [[Medal of Honour (Hong Kong)|MH]], [[Justice of Peace|JP]] (born 1951), anglicised as '''Herman Hui''', is a former chairman of the [[World Scout Committee]], the executive board for the [[World Organization of the Scout Movement]] from 2005 to 2008.
He is a Hong Kong [[Han Chinese|Chinese]] lawyer of [[British nationality]], working as a legal advisor for governmental boards and committees, and Director of the Glorious Sun investment company. He received the [[Medal of Honour (Hong Kong)|Medal of Honour]], an honorary [[Justice of the Peace]] appointment and the [[Bronze Wolf]] award for his contributions to social welfare in Hong Kong and his contributions to [[Scouting]] worldwide.
==Personal history== Hui was born and lives in Hong Kong. He was educated at [[Ying Wa College]], and later earned a [[Bachelor of Law]] degree from the [[University of Hong Kong]]. Following his studies, he was admitted to the [[Supreme court|Supreme Court]]s in Hong Kong (1976), the UK (1983) and Victoria, Australia (1985), and afterwards has been in private practice.<ref name='wosm1'>{{cite web|title=World Scout Committee elections, List of Candidates |publisher=[[World Organization of the Scout Movement]] |location=Thessaloniki |date=15 July 2002 |format=PDF |url=http://www.scout.org/wse/conf02docs/confdoc5_e.pdf |accessdate=27 August 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060828073253/http://www.scout.org/wse/conf02docs/confdoc5_e.pdf |archivedate=28 August 2006 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> In his legal function, he participates in governmental advisory boards and committees of the [[Government of Hong Kong]], including *Advisory Committee for the Support of the Employment of People with Disability (創業軒, SEPD), an activity organised by the Social Welfare Department, *Guardianship Board of the Health, Welfare and Food Bureau, *Social Welfare Advisory Committee of the Health, Welfare and Food Bureau.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.hwfb.gov.hk/en/committees | title = Advisory committees list | publisher = [[Government of Hong Kong]], Health, Welfare and Food Bureau | accessdate = 26 August 2006 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060911101005/http://www.hwfb.gov.hk/en/committees/ | archivedate = 11 September 2006 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> In 2000, Hui was awarded the [[Medal of Honour (Hong Kong)|Medal of Honour]] by the Government of Hong Kong, and on 2004-07-01 he was appointed to the honorary title of [[Justice of the Peace]].<ref name='hk1'>{{cite web | title = Miscellaneous lists in connexion with the Civil Establishment, Justices of the Peace | publisher = [[Government of Hong Kong]] | url = http://www.info.gov.hk/cml/eng/miscell/index3f.htm | accessdate = 27 August 2006}}</ref>
After being the external legal advisor of the Glorious Sun Enterprises, a 3.8 billion Hong Kong dollars (USD 500 million) investment [[holding company]] focusing on [[casual apparel]], he joined the group in 1995 as an Executive Director.<ref name='gsunannrep'>{{cite web | title = Annual Report | url = http://www.glorisun.com/pdf/Annual%20Report%20(E).pdf | format = PDF | pages = 146 pages | publisher = Glorious Sun Group | year = 2005 | accessdate = 27 August 2006}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> He is also managing director of Everight Consultants Ltd.<ref name='wosm1'/>
Hui is married and has one child.<ref name='wosm1'/>
==Scouting== Hui Chung-shing has been participating in [[Scouting]] since he was a first form student in the secondary school, Ying Wa College. He started as [[Boy Scout]] with the school's 13th Hong Kong Group, which is now the 75th Kowloon Group of [[The Scout Association of Hong Kong]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.scout.org.hk/article_attach/4835/P06-07.PDF | title = 和而不同 (in Chinese) | publisher = [[The Scout Association of Hong Kong]] | format = PDF | accessdate = 1 September 2006}}</ref> He now still holds the title of Group Scout Leader in the Scout Group.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.75scout.org/introduction06_content.php |title=Introduction to 75th Kowloon Group (in Chinese) |accessdate=1 September 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928214916/http://www.75scout.org/introduction06_content.php |archivedate=28 September 2007 }}</ref> He later became [[Scout Commissioner]], actively involved in social action projects of the Scout Association of Hong Kong, initiating exchange Scouts in Hong Kong and in China.<ref name='wosm2'>{{cite web|title=Information about the chairman |publisher=[[World Organization of the Scout Movement]] |url=http://www.scout.org/front/wscchair_e.shtml |accessdate=27 August 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061011054813/http://www.scout.org/front/wscchair_e.shtml |archivedate=11 October 2006 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
Hui was chairman of the Asia-Pacific Scout Committee from 1998 to 2001, and he was member of the [[World Organization of the Scout Movement]] (WOSM) Strategy Task Force. In 2002, he was elected as a member of the [[World Scout Committee]], the executive body of the World Organization of the Scout Movement, for a period of six years.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.scout.org/en/content/download/3617/32998/file/elections.pdf| title = Result of elections| publisher = [[World Organization of the Scout Movement]]| format = pdf| accessdate = 14 November 2007| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081207003351/http://www.scout.org/en/content/download/3617/32998/file/elections.pdf| archivedate = 7 December 2008| df = dmy-all}}</ref> During the 37th [[World Scout Conference]] in Tunisia in 2005, Hui was elected to be chairman of the Committee.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.scout.org/en/information_events/events/world_events/world_conference/37_wsc/conference_summary | title = Conference Summary | publisher = [[World Organization of the Scout Movement]] | format = pdf | accessdate = 14 November 2007 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070825040521/http://www.scout.org/en/information_events/events/world_events/world_conference/37_wsc/conference_summary | archivedate = 25 August 2007 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> His term was expected to end in 2008 with the [[World Scout Conference]] scheduled in [[Korea]], but he resigned on 2008-02-29.<ref>{{cite web | title = Announcement to National Scout Organizations | publisher = [[World Scout Bureau]] | date = March 2008 | url = http://www.scout.org/en/information_events/news/2008/announcement_to_national_scout_organizations | accessdate = 3 March 2008 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080509170701/http://scout.org/en/information_events/news/2008/announcement_to_national_scout_organizations | archivedate = 9 May 2008 | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
In 2000, Hui was awarded the [[Bronze Wolf]] award for his strong support to Scouting.<ref name='wosm1'/> He continues to be active in The Scout Association of Hong Kong as [[Deputy Commissioner|Deputy Chief Commissioner (Support)]],<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.scout.org.hk/en/history/hohks/00002513.html | title = HK Scouting Event in 2000s | accessdate = 3 September 2006}}</ref> and holds other international Scout offices.
In 2008 Hui resigned his position on the World Scout Committee, and was succeeded by [[Philippe Da Costa]].<ref name="Herman Hui resigns as Chairman of the WSC">{{cite web| last =| first =| year =2007| url =http://scout.org/en/information_events/news/2008/announcement_to_national_scout_organizations| title =Herman Hui resigns as Chairman of the WSC| format =| work =| publisher =World Organization of the Scout Movement| accessdate =3 March 2007| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20080509170701/http://scout.org/en/information_events/news/2008/announcement_to_national_scout_organizations| archivedate =9 May 2008| df =dmy-all}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Scouting}}
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.scout.org World Organization of the Scout Movement (WOSM) official website] *[http://www.info.gov.hk/mcor/english/sepd/profile.html Support of the Employment of People with Disability (SEPD) official website] *[http://www.glorisun.com Glorious Sun Enterprises official website] *[http://finance.google.com/finance?cid=671201 Financial data of Glorious Sun Enterprises on Google Finance] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060207070438/http://chinascout.org/bbs/dispbbs.asp?boardID=16&ID=4022&page=1 Hui awarding ribbons to Packs and Troops in Hong Kong] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060818134336/http://www.scout.org/press/wnews/060704.shtml.en Hui attending the awarding of the Bronze Wolf to King Bhumibol Adulyadej of Thailand]
{{S-start}} {{S-npo|wosm}} {{S-bef | before = [[Marie-Louise Correa]] }} {{S-ttl | title = Chairman, World Scout Committee | years = 2005–2008 }} {{S-aft | after = [[Philippe Da Costa]] }} {{End}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hui, Herman}} [[Category:1951 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:World Scout Committee members]] [[Category:Solicitors of Hong Kong]] [[Category:Hong Kong businesspeople]] [[Category:Recipients of the Bronze Wolf Award]] [[Category:Scouting and Guiding in Hong Kong]]

{{Infobox person | name = Jane du Pont Lunger | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = June 20, 1914 | birth_place = [[Wilmington, Delaware]], US | death_date = September 18, 2001 | death_place = Wilmington, Delaware, US | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | education = | occupation = Racehorse owner/breeder, Philanthropist | known_for = | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] | spouse = Harry William Lunger (1905–1976) | children = 5 | parents = [[Philip Frances du Pont]] (1878-1928) & Elizabeth Horner (d. 1964) | boards = |honors = Honored Lady Guest, Thoroughbred Club of America (1980) }} '''Jane du Pont Lunger''' (June 20, 1914 - September 18, 2001) was an American heiress, philanthropist, and an owner/breeder of [[Thoroughbred]] [[horse racing|racehorses]]. A sixth generation member of [[Delaware|Delaware's]] prominent [[Du Pont family]], her father, [[Philip Francis du Pont]], was a major benefactor to the [[University of Virginia]].
In 1934, Jane du Pont married Harry W. Lunger (1905–1976) who worked at [[All American Aviation|All American Aviation Company]], a company founded by [[Richard Chichester du Pont|Richard du Pont]] and based in Wilmington, Delaware. During 1936-1937 the Lungers built "Oberod," a stone mansion on rural acreage at 400 Burnt Mill Road in the Brandywine River Valley about 8 miles from downtown [[Wilmington, Delaware]].<ref>[http://www.deldot.gov/archaeology/historic_pres/brandywine_valley/pdf/scenic_river_and_highway_study.pdf New Castle County, Delaware, Department of Planning]</ref> Oberod is now owned by the Wilmington-base [[LabWare]] corporation, who use it as a training facility and to host special events.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailylocal.com/article/20120521/NEWS01/120529948/mane-event-for-reins-of-life-at-former-dupont-estate |title=Mane Event for Reins of Life at former duPont estate |publisher=Dailylocal.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-25}}</ref>
In 2005, the Jane du Pont Lunger Residual Charitable Trust donated $250,000 to the [[The Jockey Club|Grayson-Jockey Club Research Foundation, Inc.]] which underwrites [[veterinary]] research projects dedicated to the well being of horses.<ref>[http://www.jockeyclub.com/mediaCenter.asp?story=194 The Jockey Club].</ref> Her estate and family are major contributors to the [[Delaware Art Museum]].<ref>[http://www.delart.org/home.html Delaware Art Museum] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091125051829/http://www.delart.org/home.html |date=2009-11-25 }}</ref>
==Christiana Stables== In 1937, Jane and Harry Lunger established Christiana Stables, named for the community of [[Christiana, Delaware]]. Their first [[Horse trainer|trainer]] was [[Selby L. Burch|Selby Burch]], son of U.S. Racing Hall of Fame inductee, [[William P. Burch|William Burch]]. Next, [[T. J. Healey#John A. Healey|John Healey]], son of Hall of Fame trainer [[T. J. Healey|Thomas J. Healey]], took charge of Christiana Stables but he died at age 43 in 1947. Future U.S. Racing Hall of Fame inductee [[Henry S. Clark|Henry Clark]] took over and remained with the Lungers into the 1980s. He was followed by [[James W. Maloney|James Maloney]], [[William Badgett, Jr.]] and then [[James W. Murphy (horseman)|James W. Murphy]].
The Lungers raced some 45 stakes winners, many of which they bred themselves. Among their successful runners were Miss Ferdinand, [[Cyane (horse)|Cyane]], [[Dance Spell]], [[Endine]], Light Hearted, [[Obeah (horse)|Obeah]], Salem, and Thinking Cap. Following the 1976 death of her husband, Jane Lunger continued racing and breeding and enjoyed success with horses such as 1982 [[Blue Grass Stakes]] winner, [[Linkage (horse)|Linkage]]. In 1986, Jane Lunger sent her [[mare]] Obeah to [[Windfields Farm]] in [[Maryland]] where she was bred to [[Deputy Minister (horse)|Deputy Minister]]. The mating resulted in the April 6, 1987 birth of Christiana Stables' greatest foal. A filly Mrs. Lunger named [[Go For Wand]] was born at Walnut Green Farm in [[Unionville, Chester County, Pennsylvania|Unionville, Pennsylvania]] owned by her son-in law, Richard I.G. Jones.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=eAohAAAAIBAJ&sjid=y3YFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1596,6560758&dq=go+for+wand&hl=en ''The Day'' (New London, Connecticut) - October 27, 1990]</ref> After a stellar year in which Go For Wand won the 1989 [[Breeders' Cup Juvenile Fillies]] she was voted [[American Champion Two-Year-Old Filly]]. In 1990 she won six [[Graded stakes race|Grade 1]] races and earned her second [[Eclipse Award]] as the [[American Champion Three-Year-Old Filly]]. Go For Wand suffered a catastrophic injury while leading down the homestretch in the 1990 [[Breeders' Cup Distaff]] and had to be humanely [[Animal euthanasia|euthanized]]. She was inducted in the U.S. Racing Hall of Fame in 1996.<ref>[http://www.racingmuseum.org/hall/horse.asp?ID=82 Go For Wand at the National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061230041342/http://www.racingmuseum.org/hall/horse.asp?ID=82 |date=2006-12-30 }}</ref>
In 1980, Jane du Pont Lunger was recognized by the Thoroughbred Club of America as their Honored Lady Guest.<ref>[http://www.thethoroughbredclub.com/default.html Thoroughbred Club of America]</ref>
Jane du Pont Lunger was still significantly involved with racing and breeding at the time of her death in 2001 at age eighty-seven.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lunger, Jane Du Pont}} [[Category:1914 births]] [[Category:2001 deaths]] [[Category:American racehorse owners and breeders]] [[Category:American philanthropists]] [[Category:People from Wilmington, Delaware]] [[Category:Du Pont family]] [[Category:Delaware Republicans]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Jon Eubanks |office = Speaker pro tempore of the [[Arkansas House of Representatives]] |term_start = January 2015 |term_end = |predecessor = [[Darrin Williams]] |successor = |state_house1 = Arkansas |district1 = 74th |term_start1 = January 2013 |term_end1 = |predecessor1 = Butch Wilkins |successor1 = |state_house2 = Arkansas |district2 = 84th |term_start2 = January 2011 |term_end2 = January 2013 |predecessor2 = John Wells |successor2 = [[Charlie Collins (politician)|Charlie Collins]] |birth_name = Jon Scott Eubanks |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1951|10|1}} |birth_place = [[Portsmouth, Virginia]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |spouse = Janet Eubanks |children = 4 |education = [[Virginia Tech|Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University]]
[[Arkansas Tech University|Arkansas Tech University, Russellville]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Science|BS]])}} }} '''Jon Scott Eubanks''' (born October 1, 1951)[https://static.ark.org/eeuploads/arml/91st_AR_General_Assembly.pdf 91st Arkansas General Assembly Legislative Directory] is a [[farmer]] and a [[Certified Public Accountant]] in [[Paris, Arkansas|Paris]] in [[Logan County, Arkansas|Logan County]] in western [[Arkansas]], who is a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] member of the [[Arkansas House of Representatives]]. His District 74, which he has represented since 2013, includes parts of [[Logan County, Arkansas|Logan]], [[Franklin County, Arkansas|Franklin]], [[Scott County, Arkansas|Scott]], and [[Sebastian County, Arkansas|Sebastian]] counties. He represented House District 84 from 2011 to 2013, prior to decennial redistricting. Since 2015, Eubanks has been the House Speaker Pro Tempore. ==Background== Eubanks graduated from high school in the capital city of [[Annapolis, Maryland|Annapolis]], [[Maryland]]. He attended [[Virginia Tech]] at [[Blacksburg, Virginia|Blacksburg]], [[Virginia (U.S. state)|Virginia]], and in 1990 received a degree in accounting from [[Arkansas Tech University]] in [[Russellville, Arkansas|Russellville]] in [[Pope County, Arkansas|Pope County]]. He is a past president of his local [[Farm Bureau]] and of the Paris division of the [[Boys and Girls Clubs of America]]. He is a former president of the Paris [[Rotary International]]. He and his wife, Janet, have four children, Chris, Nick, Stacy, and Andrew. The couple attends [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]].{{cite web|url=http://www.arkansashouse.org/member/265/ |title=Jon Eubanks, R-74 |publisher=arkansashouse.org |accessdate=January 4, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140105060119/http://www.arkansashouse.org/member/265/ |archivedate=January 5, 2014 |df= }} He is a former volunteer for the [[Boy Scouts of America]]. ==Political life== Prior to his legislative service, Eubanks served on the Paris School Board.{{cite web|url=http://votesmart.org/candidate/biography/119183/jon-eubanks#.UsjBZJV3uZM|title=Jon Scott Eubanks' Biography|publisher=votesmart.org|accessdate=January 4, 2014}} In 2010, he was elected in House District 84 by defeating the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] David L. Rush, 3,990 (56.4 percent) to 3,085 (43.6 percent). The seat was vacated by the [[Term limits|term-limited]] Democrat John Wells.{{cite web|url=http://ballotpedia.org/Arkansas_House_of_Representatives_elections,_2010|title=District 84|publisher=ballotpedia.org|accessdate=January 4, 2014}} Switched to House District 74, Eubanks in 2012 defeated another Democrat, Daniel Wall, 7,257 (72.2 percent) to 2,788 (27.8 percent). The incumbent Democrat in the district, Butch Wilkins, was transferred to District 59 via [[redistricting]].{{cite web|url=http://ballotpedia.org/Arkansas_House_of_Representatives_elections,_2012|title=District 74|publisher=ballotpedia.org|accessdate=January 4, 2014}} Eubanks is a member of the Arkansas Legislative Council and the House committees on (1) Agriculture, Forestry and Economic Development, (2) Education, (3) Energy, and (4) Performance Review. He is a member of the [[Conservative (politics)|conservative]] [[American Legislative Exchange Council]] (ALEC). In 2013 Eubanks joined the required majority to [[Veto override|override]] the vetoes of Democratic Governor [[Mike Beebe]] to enact legislation to require photo identification for casting a ballot in Arkansas and to ban abortion after twenty weeks of gestation. He had co-sponsored both measures. Eubanks supported related [[pro-life]] legislation to ban abortion whenever fetal heartbeat is detected, to forbid the inclusion of abortion in the state insurance exchange, and to make the death of an unborn child a [[felony]] in certain cases. He co-sponsored a spending cap in the state budget, but the measure failed to gain approval by two votes in the House. Eubanks co-sponsored legislation to empower officials of higher education and religious institutions to engage in [[concealed carry]] of firearms for public safety. He voted to prohibit the governor from regulating firearms in an emergency. Eubanks supported legislation to make the office of prosecuting attorney in Arkansas [[nonpartisan]]. He supported the bill, signed by Governor Beebe, to permit the sale of up to five hundred gallons per month of [[pasteurization|unpasteurized]] whole milk directly from the farm to consumers. He did not vote on a failed proposal to prohibit the closure of public schools based on declining enrollments over a two-year period. In 2011, Eubanks supported a dress code for public schools. He backed curriculum standards for biblical instruction in public schools. He voted for the Capital Gains Reduction Act and for a tax reduction on manufacturers' utilities. He voted to permit driver's license tests only in the English language, but the measure failed in the House. He voted against cell phone use in school zones. He voted against the 2011 congressional [[redistricting]] bill.{{cite web|url=http://votesmart.org/candidate/key-votes/119183/jon-eubanks#.UsjDqJV3uZM|title=Jon Scott Eubanks' Voting Records|publisher=votesmart.org|accessdate=January 4, 2014}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-ar-hs}} {{s-bef|before=John Wells}} {{s-ttl|title=Member of the [[Arkansas House of Representatives]]
from the 84th district|years=2011–2013}} {{s-aft|after=[[Charlie Collins (politician)|Charlie Collins]]}} |- {{s-bef|before=Butch Wilkins}} {{s-ttl|title=Member of the [[Arkansas House of Representatives]]
from the 74th district|years=2013–present}} {{s-inc|rows=2}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Darrin Williams]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Speaker pro tempore of the [[Arkansas House of Representatives]]|years=2015–present}} {{s-end}} {{Arkansas House of Representatives}} {{Current Speakers of U.S. state Houses of Representatives}} {{Portalbar|Biography|Arkansas|Politics|Conservatism|Schools|Business and Economics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Eubanks, Jon}} [[Category:1951 births]] [[Category:21st-century American politicians]] [[Category:American accountants]] [[Category:Arkansas Republicans]] [[Category:Arkansas Tech University alumni]] [[Category:Farmers from Arkansas]] [[Category:Farmers from Maryland]] [[Category:Latter Day Saints from Arkansas]] [[Category:Latter Day Saints from Maryland]] [[Category:Latter Day Saints from Virginia]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the Arkansas House of Representatives]] [[Category:People associated with the Boy Scouts of America]] [[Category:People from Paris, Arkansas]] [[Category:Politicians from Annapolis, Maryland]] [[Category:School board members in Arkansas]] [[Category:Virginia Tech alumni]]

{{Use New Zealand English|date=November 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox officeholder |honorific-prefix = |name = Joseph Dodson |honorific-suffix = |image = Joseph Reid Dodson.jpg |imagesize = |alt = Formal standing portrait of an older man |caption = Joseph Dodson |order = 1st |office = Mayor of Nelson, New Zealand |term_start = 1 May 1874 |term_end = 8 January 1875 |predecessor = |successor = |term_start2 = 16 December 1877 |term_end2 = 22 November 1881 |predecessor2 = |successor2 = |birth_date = 1811 or 1812 |birth_place = |death_date = 12 October 1890 |death_place = [[Nelson, New Zealand|Nelson]] |restingplace = [[Wakapuaka Cemetery]] |restingplacecoordinates = {{coord|-41.25771|173.30337|dim:500_region:NZ_type:landmark|display=inline|name=Wakapuaka Cemetery}} |birthname = |nationality = |spouse = |relations = [[Henry Dodson]] (brother) |party = |religion = [[Anglicanism|Anglican]] |profession = brewer }} '''Joseph Reid Dodson''' [[Justice of the Peace|JP]] (1811/12 – 12 October 1890), was the first [[Mayor of Nelson, New Zealand|Mayor of Nelson]] in New Zealand from 1874. He was a prominent brewer and Resident MagistrateEditorial, pg2, Nelson Evening Mail, 2 February 1881 in Nelson and his sixth generation descendants still operate a brewery in the city. ==Early life== Dodson was originally from England.{{cite web|title=A Nelson brewing family |url=http://www.theprow.org.nz/nelson-brewing-family/ |publisher=The Prow |accessdate=1 December 2010 }} He arrived in [[Nelson, New Zealand|Nelson]] on 16 May 1854 from Melbourne in Australia on the [[brig]] [[Return (ship)|''Return'']] (via Wellington).{{cite news|title=Shipping Intelligence|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=NENZC18540520.2.3 |accessdate=1 December 2010|newspaper=Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle |volume=XIII |issue=637 |date=20 May 1854 |page=2}} Within days, he bought a share of a Nelson brewery. Soon afterwards, he returned to Melbourne to sort out his business affairs.{{cite news|title=Obituary|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=NEM18901013.2.8|accessdate=1 December 2010|newspaper=Nelson Evening Mail |volume=XXIV |issue=242 |date=13 October 1890 |page=2}} He returned with his wife and four children on the [[Marchioness (ship)|''Marchioness'']], arriving on 27 September 1854.{{cite news|title=Shipping Intelligence|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=NENZC18540930.2.3 |accessdate=1 December 2010|newspaper=Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle |volume=XIII |issue=671 |date=30 September 1854 |page=2}} ==Professional career== After his first arrival from Melbourne, Dodson bought the shares of the late Dr Renwick in the Hooper & Co brewery. In 1855, he established the Raglan Brewery and leased Charles Harley's Bridge Street Brewery. In 1860, he sold his brewery shares and went back to England with his family for six years. On his return to Nelson, he brought farming equipment with him and established himself as a reseller of these goods. Once he was established, he took up a shareholding in Hooper & Co again. In 1884, Dodson suffered a significant loss with the death of his business partner of 30 years, George Hooper. Dodson took over Hooper's shareholding, and the name of the brewery changed to ''J. R. Dodson & Son''. His son Henry had joined the business in 1879. Henry Duncan joined them in 1888; he was the son of Joseph Dodson's daughter Mary-Ann. Descendants of Henry Duncan have continued brewing. His great-grandchildren Matt Duncan and Callum Duncan now operate a boutique brewery of international acclaim. Founders Brewery, established in 1999, was the first fully certified organic brewery in the southern hemisphere. They have twice won the award of ''Champion Small Brewery'' at the [[Australian International Beer Awards]].{{cite news|title=Sons continue brewing tradition |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/marlborough-express/lifestyle/2392379 |accessdate=2 December 2010|newspaper=The Marlborough Express |date=7 May 2009 }} ==Political career== Dodson was former member of the Board of Works. He was elected a Councillor, possibly in 1874, and elected by his fellow Councillors as Mayor at a Council meeting on 1 May 1874.{{cite news|title=Election of Mayor |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=NEM18740502.2.8.1|accessdate=2 December 2010 |newspaper=Nelson Evening Mail |volume=IX |issue=104 |date=2 May 1874 |page=2 }} He was appointed [[Justice of the Peace]] in 1874.{{cite news|title=The Nelson Evening Mail|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=NEM18740608.2.9|accessdate=2 December 2010 |newspaper=Nelson Evening Mail |volume=IX |issue=135 |date=8 June 1874 }} Dodson did not receive a salary as Mayor{{cite news|title=The Nelson Evening Mail |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=NEM18740618.2.7 |accessdate=2 December 2010 |newspaper=Nelson Evening Mail |volume=IX |issue=144 |date=18 June 1874 |page=2 }} although he entertained visiting dignitaries at his own expense, such as the [[Governor-General of New Zealand|Governor]] [[Sir James Fergusson, 6th Baronet|Sir James Fergusson]] on behalf of the city. This provoked some debate in the local papers about the behaviour of the Provincial Superintendent in comparison.{{cite news |title=The Nelson Evening Mail |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=NEM18740620.2.7 |accessdate=2 December 2010 |newspaper=Nelson Evening Mail |volume=IX |issue=146 |date=20 June 1874 |page=2 }} During his term negotiations began with the local Gas Works, a Provincial Government owned facility, for gas lighting for the city.{{cite news|title=Editorial |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=TS18740912.2.6 |accessdate=7 December 2010 |newspaper=The Star |date=12 September 1874|issue=2033 |page=2 }} In September 1874 the Council sought to employ the first town clerk and rate collector.{{cite news|title=The Grey River Argus|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=GRA18740926.2.6 |accessdate=7 December 2010 |newspaper=Grey River Argus |volume=XV |issue=1916 |date=26 September 1874 |page=2}} On 16 December 1874 Dodson was reconfirmed as Mayor for 1875.{{cite news|title=Editorial |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=TC18741217.2.5 |accessdate=7 December 2010 |newspaper=Colonist |volume=XVII |issue=1850 |date=17 December 1874 |page=2 }} The council was in conflict with the [[Nelson Province|provincial government]] over finances. Nelson went bankrupt, the mayor resigned on 8 January 1875, and so did most of the councillors.{{cite web|title=Mayors of Nelson |url=http://www.theprow.org.nz/mayors-of-nelson/ |publisher=The Prow |accessdate=25 October 2010 }}{{cite book |title = The Cyclopedia of New Zealand : Nelson, Marlborough & Westland Provincial Districts |year = 1906 |url = http://www.nzetc.org/tm/scholarly/tei-Cyc05Cycl-t1-body1-d1-d1-d5.html |author=Cyclopedia Company Limited |accessdate = 25 October 2010 |location = Christchurch |chapter = Ex Mayors |pages = 41–42 }} A special meeting of the remaining Councillors was held on 12 January 1875 to appoint a new Mayor but no one was forthcoming. A public meeting was held on the Friday to determine the wishes of the ratepayers.''Editorial'', The Nelson Evening Mail, pg 2, 13 January 1875 In mid February, seven people stood for Council and since that was the number of vacancies, they were declared elected.{{cite news|title=City Council|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=NEM18750216.2.9 |accessdate=2 December 2010 |newspaper=Nelson Evening Mail |volume=X |issue=40 |date=16 February 1875 |page=2}} At a council meeting on 26 February, a new mayor was elected and [[Joseph Levien]] accepted the position.{{cite news|title=City Council |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=NEM18750227.2.8.3 |accessdate=2 December 2010 |newspaper=Nelson Evening Mail |volume=X |issue=50 |date=27 February 1875 |page=2 }} Dodson served a second period as mayor, from 16 December 1877 until he retired on 22 November 1881.{{cite news|title=Editorial|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=NEM18811123.2.8&srpos=667&e=01-01-1881-31-12-1881--10--661-byDA---0dodson--|accessdate=10 December 2010 |newspaper=Nelson Evening Mail|volume=XVI |issue=279 |date=23 November 1881 |page=2 }} This was described as a 'happier term'. The city hosted another Governor during this term, [[Hercules Robinson, 1st Baron Rosmead|The Lord Rosmead]]. Also during his term, Dodson and the Council lobbied Government to extend the existing railway and link it to the main line at Blenheim. When Dodson retired as Mayor, Edward Everett was elected in his place. ==Death== Dodson died on 12 October 1890 in Nelson, aged 78 years. He was buried at [[Wakapuaka Cemetery]] on 14 October.{{cite web|title=Cemeteries database |url=http://www.nelsoncitycouncil.co.nz/cemeteries-database-2/ |publisher=Nelson City Council|accessdate=2 December 2010|page=search for Dodson}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-new | first}} {{s-ttl | rows = 2 | title = [[Mayor of Nelson, New Zealand|Mayor of Nelson]] |years = 1874–1875
1877–1881}} {{s-aft | after = [[Joseph Levien]] }} {{s-bef | before = [[William Reid Waters|William Waters]]}} {{s-aft | after = [[Edward William Everett]] }} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dodson, Joseph Reid}} [[Category:1812 births]] [[Category:1890 deaths]] [[Category:Mayors of Nelson, New Zealand]] [[Category:New Zealand businesspeople]] [[Category:Politicians from Melbourne]] [[Category:Burials at Wakapuaka Cemetery]] [[Category:19th-century Australian politicians]] [[Category:19th-century New Zealand politicians]]

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Jujiro Matsuda
松田 重次郎 | image = Jujiro-matsuda.jpg | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth-date|August 8, 1875}} | birth_place = [[Hiroshima]], Japan | death_date = {{Death-date and age|March 27, 1952|August 8, 1875}} | death_place = Hiroshima, Japan | occupation = [[Entrepreneur|Founder]], [[Mazda|Mazda Motor Corporation]] | spouse = }} {{Nihongo|'''Jujiro Matsuda'''|松田 重次郎|Matsuda Jūjirō|August 8, 1875 – March 27, 1952}} was a [[Japanese people|Japanese]] industrialist and businessman who founded automobile manufacturer [[Mazda|Mazda Motor Corporation]]. ==Early life== The son of a [[fisherman]], Jujiro Matsuda was born in [[Hiroshima]]. He was apprenticed to a blacksmith in [[Osaka]] at the age of fourteen and invented the "Matsuda-type pump" in 1906. Later, he took over management of the foundry at which he apprenticed and changed the name of the organization to "Matsuda Pump Partnership". He was forced out of his company, but started an [[weapon|armament]] manufacturer soon after – the eponymously named Matsuda Works. Matsuda would see his fledgling company's fortunes improve when it was commissioned as a supplier to the [[Tsar]] of Russia{{cite web|url=http://www.drivingtoday.com/wbz4/greatest_cars/mazda_mx5_miata/index.html |title=Mazda MX-5 by Jack Nerad for Driving Today |accessdate=2007-07-25 |publisher=Driving Today |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928004629/http://www.drivingtoday.com/wbz4/greatest_cars/mazda_mx5_miata/index.html |archivedate=2007-09-28 |deadurl=yes |df= }} as well as manufacturing the [[Type 99 rifle]] for the [[Military of Japan|Japanese military]]. ==Toyo Kogyo and Mazda== By 1921, Jujiro Matsuda was a wealthy man thanks to his previous business ventures. He moved back to [[Hiroshima]] when he was asked to take over management of floundering artificial [[Cork (material)|cork]] manufacturer {{Nihongo|Toyo Cork Kogyo Co., Ltd.|東洋コルク工業株式会社|Tōyō Koruku Kōgyō Kabushiki Gaisha}}, which was placed into receivership by its creditors when the market for artificial cork dried up following the end of World War I. The unprofitable cork business ceased, and Matsuda focused on tool manufacturing. 1931 oversaw the introduction of the "[[Mazda Mazdago|Mazdago]]" motorized tricycle,{{cite web|url=http://www.mazda.com/en/innovation/mazda-stories/mazda/behind/ |title=A Story Behind the Name of “Mazda” |accessdate=2018-10-30 |publisher=Mazda }} manufactured in what is now [[Fuchū, Hiroshima (Aki)|Fuchū city]] and the company, now known as {{Nihongo|Toyo Kogyo Co., Ltd.|東洋工業株式会社|Tōyō Kōgyō Kabushiki Gaisha}}, would set its focus on motor vehicle manufacturing. The Toyo Kogyo headquarters saw heavy damage on August 6, 1945 upon the [[Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki|bombing of Hiroshima]]. The [[Fuchū, Hiroshima (Aki)|Fuchū city]] plant, located over 5 kilometers from the epicenter of the nuclear explosion was left relatively unscathed, and Matsuda offered its use for the Hiroshima bureau of [[NHK]]. Matsuda was not accused of being nor was he charged as a war conspirator, and a revitalized Toyo Kogyo was the main force behind repairing the damaged economy of Hiroshima following World War II. In 1950, Toyo Kogyo provided startup for a [[baseball]] team, the [[Hiroshima Carp]]. His adopted son-in-law, Tsuneji Matsuda succeeded him as president of Toyo Kogyo, and oversaw the expansion of its automobile division until 1979, when [[Ford Motor Company]] took a 25% equity stake in Toyo Kogyo. The alliance with Ford led to the divestiture of shares from the Matsuda family and the change of Toyo Kogyo into [[Mazda Motor Corporation]] in 1984. The Matsuda family still owns a controlling interest in the [[Hiroshima Toyo Carp]]. Matsuda died on March 27, 1952. For his contributions to [[Hiroshima Prefecture]], a bronze statue of Jujiro Matsuda was created in 1965 by [[Onomichi, Hiroshima]] native, sculptor Katsuzou Entsuba and was erected at the Hijiyama Park in [[Minami-ku, Hiroshima]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Matsuda, Jujiro}} [[Category:1875 births]] [[Category:1952 deaths]] [[Category:Japanese businesspeople]] [[Category:Japanese founders of automobile manufacturers]] [[Category:People from Hiroshima]] [[Category:Mazda]] [[Category:Automotive pioneers]]
