{{Korean name|Lee}} {{Infobox person | name = Lee Kun-hee | image = Lee Kun-Hee.jpg | caption = Lee attending breakfast with various Korean business leaders, 2013 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1942|1|9|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Uiryeong County|Ŭiryŏng]], [[South Gyeongsang|South Kyŏngsang]], [[Korea under Japanese rule|Japanese occupied Korea]] (present day [[South Korea]]){{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Lee-Kun-Hee|title=Lee Kun-Hee South Korean businessman|publisher=Britannica |author=Louis Kraar|date=12 Apr 2010|accessdate=18 Feb 2017}} | nationality = [[South Korea]]n | alma_mater = [[Waseda University]]
[[George Washington University]] | occupation = [[Chairman]] of [[Samsung]] | spouse = [[Hong Ra-hee]]{{cite web|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20110329000654|title=Hong Ra-hee makes comeback as Leeum's director|first=The Korea|last=Herald|date=29 March 2011|publisher=}} | children =[[Lee Jae-yong (businessman)|Lee Jae-yong]]
[[Lee Boo-jin]]
Lee Seo-hyun
[[Lee Yoon-hyung]]† | parents = [[Lee Byung-chul]]
Park Du-eul | module = {{Infobox Korean name|child=yes | hangul = {{linktext|이|건|희}} | hanja = {{linktext|李|健|熙}} | rr = I Geonhui | mr = Yi Kŏnhŭi}} | religion = | networth = US$16.7 billion (October 2018){{Citation | type = profile | url = https://www.forbes.com/profile/lee-kun-hee/ | title = Lee Kun-Hee | journal = Forbes | access-date = 2 May 2018}} }} '''Lee Kun-hee''' ({{Korean|hangul = 이건희 |hanja={{Lang|ko|李健熙}}}}; {{IPA-ko|iːɡʌnhi}}; born January 9, 1942) is a South Korean business magnate and the [[chairman]] of [[Samsung Group]]. In 1996, Lee became a member of the [[International Olympic Committee]]. With an estimated net worth of $70.2 billion, he and his family rank among the [[Forbes]] richest people in the world. He is the third son of [[Samsung]] founder [[Lee Byung-chul]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/8584702.stm|title=Profile: Lee Kun-hee|publisher=BBC |accessdate=2013-03-02|date=March 24, 2010}} He resigned in April 2008, owing to a Samsung slush funds scandal, but returned on March 24, 2010. In May 2014, he was hospitalized for a heart attack.{{cite news|last1=Power|first1=John|title=Is Samsung chairman Lee Kun-hee dead or alive?|url=http://www.koreaobserver.com/lee-kun-hee-dead-alive-health-of-samsung-chairman-lee-kun-hee-27791/|accessdate=7 April 2015|publisher=The Korea Observer|date=7 April 2015}} In 2014, Lee was named the world's 35th most powerful person and the most powerful Korean by [[Forbes Magazine's List of The World's Most Powerful People]] along with his son [[Lee Jae-yong (businessman)|Lee Jae-yong]].{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/powerful-people/list/#tab:overall|title=The World's Most Powerful People|publisher=}} ==Early life== [[File:李健熙和父亲李秉喆.jpg|thumb|left|Young Lee Kun-hee with his father Lee Byung-chul]] Lee Kun-hee was born on 10 January 1942 in Uiryeong, South Gyeongsang, during the [[Korea under Japanese rule|Japanese occupation of Korea]]. He is the third son of [[Lee Byung-chul]], the founder of the Samsung group. ==Career== ===Samsung=== Lee joined the [[Samsung Group]] in 1968 and took over the chairmanship on December 24, 1987, just two weeks after the death of his father, [[Lee Byung-chul]], who founded Samsung.{{Cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/2012/11/30/3709688/samsung-25-years-lee-kun-hee |title=King of Samsung: a chairman's reign of cunning and corruption |last=Byford |first=Sam |date=30 November 2012 |access-date=2018-09-27}} In the early 1990s, believing that [[Samsung Group]] was overly focused on producing massive quantities of low-quality goods and that it was not prepared to compete in quality, Lee famously said in 1993 "Change everything except your wife and kids" and true to his word attempted to reform the profoundly Korean culture that had pervaded Samsung until this point. Foreign employees were brought in and local employees were shipped out as Lee tried to foster a more international attitude to doing business. Under Lee's guidance, the company has been transformed from a Korean budget name into a major international force and arguably{{According to whom|date=July 2017}} the most prominent Asian brand worldwide. One of the group's subsidiaries, Samsung Electronics, is now one of the world's leading developers and producers of semiconductors, and was listed in [[Fortune magazine]]'s list of the 100 largest corporations in the world in 2007. Today Samsung's revenues are now 39 times what they were in 1987, it generates around 20 percent of South Korea's GDP, and Lee is the country's richest man.{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2012/11/30/3709688/samsung-25-years-lee-kun-hee|title=King of Samsung: a chairman's reign of cunning and corruption|first=Sam|last=Byford|date=30 November 2012|website=The Verge}} On April 21, 2008, he resigned and stated: "We, including myself, have caused troubles to the nation with the special probe; I deeply apologize for that, and I'll take full responsibility for everything, both legally and morally."{{Cite newspaper|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7359992.stm|title=BBC News - Asia-Pacific - Samsung chief resigns from post|website=news.bbc.co.uk|date=2008-04-22}} On December 29, 2009, the South Korean government moved to pardon Lee Kun-hee. On March 24, 2010, he announced his return to Samsung Electronics as its chairman.[https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/biz/2010/03/123_62923.html "Lee Kun-hee Returns to Samsung Helm"] In an interview, Lee expressed pride in the fact that Samsung attracts the brightest minds in [[South Korea]] but added that his new goal is to attract talent from all over the world to ensure that Samsung will remain one of the top companies in the world for years. Notable Samsung industrial subsidiaries include [[Samsung Electronics]] (the [[List of the largest technology companies|world's largest information technology company]] measured by 2011 revenues),{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/c48d477a-0c3b-11df-8b81-00144feabdc0.html |title=Technology - Samsung beats HP to pole position |publisher=Ft.com |accessdate=2010-09-04}}[http://www.economist.com/businessfinance/displayStory.cfm?story_id=13788472 Economist.com] Succession at Samsung – Crowning success [[Samsung Heavy Industries]] (the world's largest [[shipbuilder]] measured by 2010 revenues),{{cite news|last=Park |first=Kyunghee |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aO0FeeTB6_0Y |title=July 29 (Bloomberg) – Samsung Heavy Shares Gain on Shell’s Platform Orders (Update1) |publisher=Bloomberg |date=2009-07-28 |accessdate=2010-11-11}} [[Samsung Engineering]] and [[Samsung C&T]] (respectively the world's 35th- and 72nd-largest construction companies),{{cite web|url=http://www.samsungsem.com/global/about-us/information/overview/index.jsp|title=SAMSUNG ELECTRO-MECHANICS|website=www.samsungsem.com}}[[Samsung Electro-Mechanics Co. Ltd.]] (Established in 1973, Samsung Electro-Mechanics has become a remarkable developer and manufacturer of key electronic components not only in Korea but also in other parts of the world) and [[Samsung Techwin]] (a [[weapons technology]] and [[optoelectronics]] manufacturer).{{cite web|url=http://enr.construction.com/toplists/InternationalContractors/001-100.asp |title=The Top 225 International Contractors2010 |publisher=Enr.construction.com |date=2010-08-25 |accessdate=2010-11-11}} Other notable subsidiaries include [[Samsung Life Insurance]] (the world's 14th-largest life insurance company),{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/global500/2009/industries/183/index.html |title=Global 500 2009: Industry: - FORTUNE on CNNMoney.com |publisher=Money.cnn.com |date=2009-07-20 |accessdate=2010-09-04}} [[Samsung Everland]] (operator of Everland Resort, the oldest [[theme park]] in South Korea){{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/2002/03/21/0321feat_6.html|title= The World's Best Amusement Parks |publisher=Forbes.com|date=2002-03-21 |accessdate=2010-09-11|first=Christina|last=Valhouli}} and [[Cheil Worldwide]] (the world's 19th-largest advertising agency measured by 2010 revenues).{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/snapshot/snapshot.asp?ticker=030000:KS|title=Cheil Worldwide Inc (030000:Korea SE)|publisher=businessweek.com|date=2010-09-15|accessdate=2010-09-16|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121005152815/http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/snapshot/snapshot.asp?ticker=030000:KS|archivedate=2012-10-05|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://adage.com/agencyfamilytrees2010/|title=Agency Family Trees 2010 |publisher=Advertising Age |date=2010-04-26 |accessdate=2010-09-16}} Samsung produces around a fifth of South Korea's total exports{{cite news|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/technology/article3764352.ece|title=Samsung chairman charged with tax evasion - Times Online|last=Hutson|first=Graham|author2=Richards, Jonathan |date=17 April 2008|work=[[The Times]]|accessdate=28 February 2011|location=London}} and its revenues are larger than many countries' [[GDP]]; in 2006, it would have been the world's 35th-largest economy.{{cite web |url=http://www.chosun.com/economy/news/200602/200602130520.html |script-title=ko:[초 국가기업] <上> 삼성 매출>싱가포르 GDP… 국가를 가르친다 – 조선닷컴 |publisher=Chosun.com |accessdate=2010-11-11 |title=Archived copy |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101128123326/http://www.chosun.com/economy/news/200602/200602130520.html |archive-date=2010-11-28 |dead-url=yes |df= }} The company has a powerful influence on South Korea's economic development, politics, media and culture and has been a major driving force behind the "[[Miracle on the Han River]]".{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/21530984|title=Samsung and its attractions - Asia’s new model company|accessdate=11 January 2012|publisher=The Economist|date=1 October 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/21538104|title=South Korea’s economy - What do you do when you reach the top?|accessdate=11 January 2012|publisher=The Economist|date=12 November 2011 }} ====Samsung scandal==== On January 14, 2008, Korean police raided Lee's home and office in an ongoing probe into accusations that Samsung was responsible for a slush fund used to bribe influential prosecutors, judges, and political figures in South Korea.[http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/01/14/business/samsung.php] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080117233025/http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/01/14/business/samsung.php |date=January 17, 2008 }} On April 4, 2008, Lee denied allegations against him in the scandal.{{cite web|url=http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/281425.html |title=Samsung chairman hints at possible resignation : National : Home |language=ko |publisher=English.hani.co.kr |date= |accessdate=2010-12-28}} After a second round of questioning by the South Korean prosecutors, on April 11, 2008, Lee was quoted by reporters as saying, "I am responsible for everything. I will assume full moral and legal responsibility.” On July 16, 2008, ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported the Seoul Central District Court had found Lee guilty on charges of financial wrongdoing and tax evasion. Prosecutors requested Lee be sentenced to seven years in prison and fined 350 billion won (approx $312 million USD). The court fined him 110 billion won (approx $98 million USD) and sentenced him to three years' suspended jail time. Lee has not responded to the verdict.{{citation needed|date=September 2018}} Months later, South Korean president [[Lee Myung-bak]] pardoned Lee so he could remain on the International Olympic Committee. In 2010, the company's former chief legal counsel, Kim Yong-chul, published a book called "Think Samsung". It revealed shocking alleged details of Lee Kun-hee's personal corruption, claiming he stole up to 10 trillion won (approx $8.9 billion USD) from Samsung subsidiaries, destroyed evidence, and bribed government officials to ensure the smooth transfer of power to his son. ==Personal life== Lee Kun-hee's wife, [[Hong Ra-hee]], is the daughter of [[Hong Jin-ki]], the former chairman of the JoongAng Ilbo and Tongyang Broadcasting Company, and Kim Yoon-nam. Kim was born in the coastal city of Mokpo, South Jeolla. While attending Ewha Womans University as a junior in 1943, she married Hong Jin-ki (1917–86), who at the time was working as a judge at the Jeonju District Court in Jeonju, North Jeolla. The two are survived by four sons and two daughters: Ra-hee, director general of Leeum, Samsung Museum of Art and the wife of Lee Kun-hee; Seok-hyun; Seok-joh, CEO of BGF Retail; Suk-joon, CEO of Bokwang Investment; Seok-kyu, CEO of Bokwang; and Ra-young, deputy director at Leeum. Kim was also the mother-in-law of Cholsoo Charles Lho, publisher of the Korea JoongAng Daily. Kim Youn-nam died of natural causes at Samsung Medical Center in Gangnam District, southern Seoul in 2013 when she was 90 years old.{{cite web|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2972683|title=JoongAng's late chairman's wife dies|website=Korea JoongAng Daily}} Hong Ra-hee majored in applied art at Seoul National University and gained experience as a museum art director in 1995 at Ho-am Art Museum in Yongin, Gyeonggi Province. The museum was established by Samsung founder Lee Byung-chul in 1978. His siblings and some of their children are also executives of major Korean business groups.[https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20101203/ap_on_hi_te/as_skorea_samsung Samsung promotes chairman's son to president] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101205024515/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20101203/ap_on_hi_te/as_skorea_samsung |date=December 5, 2010 }}, Kelly olsen, AP, 3 Dec 2010 [[Lee Boo-jin]], his eldest daughter, is president and CEO of [[Hotel Shilla]], a luxury hotel chain, as well as president of [[Samsung Everland]], a theme park and resort operator that is "widely seen as the de facto holding company for the conglomerate" according to Associated Press. As of 2010, his son [[Lee Jae-yong (businessman)|Lee Jae-yong]] is vice chairman of [[Samsung Electronics]]. Lee has 4 children: the eldest child and the only son [[Lee Jae-yong (businessman)|Lee Jae-yong]] (born 1968) and three daughters Lee Boo-jin (born 1970), Lee Seo-hyun (born 1973) and [[Lee Yoon-hyung]] (born 1979, died 2005)†.{{Cite web |url=http://news.163.com/10/0824/16/6ES8V5TG000146BD_2.html |title=The descendants of the Samsung family lived uncomfortably and their suicides were killed (2) |date=24 August 2010 |access-date=2018-09-27}} [[File:Kim Jae-Yeol from acrofan.jpg|thumb|right|{{ill|Kim Jae-Yeol|ko|김재열 (기업인)}}, the son in law of Lee Kun-hee, and husband of Lee Seo-hyun]] Lee's eldest brother's son is currently chairman and CEO of the [[CJ Group]], a company holding businesses in food, beverages and adult entertainment. His second eldest brother's sons ran Saehan Media, one of the largest blank media producers. His older sister is the owner of [[Hansol]] Group, the country's largest paper manufacturer and producer of electronics and [[telecommunications]]. One of his sisters is married to Koo Ja-hak, brother of a former chairman of the [[LG Group]] and himself a former chairman of LG Semiconductor. He is currently running one of the largest food services firms in South Korea. Lee's younger sister, Lee Myung-hee, is chairwoman of the [[Shinsegae Group]], the largest retail company in South Korea, with major holdings such as the [[Shinsegae|Shinsegae Department Store]]s and E-Mart. His daughter [[Lee Yoon-hyung]] committed suicide in Manhattan in 2005.The Seoul Times : [http://theseoultimes.com/ST/?url=/ST/db/read.php?idx=2724 Samsung Chairman's Daughter Kills Herself] in November 2005. Retrieved January 19, 2017 In late 2005, Lee was tested for cancer at the [[MD Anderson|MD Anderson Medical Center]] in [[Houston]], Texas.[http://www.useoul.edu/snunews?bm=v&bbsidx=72074&page=11 Finding a Cure for Cancer | News | SNU Media | News & Forum | SNU] Lee's older brother Lee Maeng-hee and older sister Lee Sook-hee initiated legal action against him in February 2012, asking a South Korean court to award them shares of Samsung companies totaling US$850 million (913.563 billion [[South Korean Won|won]]), which they claim their father willed to them.{{cite news| url=https://blogs.wsj.com/korearealtime/2012/05/30/samsung-feud-the-court-case-begins/ | work=The Wall Street Journal | title=Samsung Feud: The Court Case Begins | date=May 30, 2012 | accessdate=May 30, 2012}} Court hearings began in May 2012. On February 6, 2014, courts in South Korea dismissed the case.{{Cite newspaper|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-26066975|title=Samsung boss Lee Kun-hee wins inheritance case appeal|journal=BBC News|date=6 February 2014|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} On May 11, 2014, Lee was hospitalized for a heart attack. On May 16, 2014, the AsiaN claimed that Lee had died, citing a whistleblower inside the firm. It deleted the article seven months later, saying it was unable to obtain further information to substantiate the claim. Lee speaks [[Korean language|Korean]], English, and [[Japanese language|Japanese]]. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commonscat|Lee_Kun-Hee}} * [https://www.forbes.com/profile/lee-kun-hee/ Forbes.com: Forbes World's Richest People] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070314002043/http://times.hankooki.com/lpage/opinion/200601/kt2006010821132854090.htm "Lee Kun-hee's Big Stick"], The Korea Times, January 8, 2006. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090326091555/http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/01/14/business/samsung.php "Samsung chairman's office raided as part of inquiry"], International Herald Tribune, January 14, 2008. * [http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/281425.html "Samsung chairman hints at possible resignation"], Hankoryeh Newspaper, April 11, 2008. * [http://www.leekunhee.com/en/enchair_info.jsp "www.leekunhee.com"]{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Official personal bio * [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB126206742869108631 "South Korea Plans to Pardon Former Samsung Chairman"] {{S-start}} {{S-bus}} {{s-bef|before=[[Lee Byung-chul]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Chairman of [[Samsung Group]]|years=December 1987 – April 2008}} {{s-aft|after=[[Lee Soo-bin]]}} {{s-bef|before=[[Lee Soo-bin]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Chairman of [[Samsung Group]]|years=March 2010 – present}} {{s-inc}} {{S-end}} revision.text:
'''Louis Leplée''' (April 7, 1883 in Bayonne, France – April 6, 1936 in Paris, France) was a [[France|French]] nightclub owner<ref>{{cite book|last1=Margerison|first1=Charles|title=Amazing Musicians: Inspirational Stories|date=2012|publisher=Amazing People Club|isbn=1921752912|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_Qi_OIUiD44C}}</ref> who discovered the French singer [[Édith Piaf]] singing on a Paris street corner in 1935.<ref name=taylor>{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Music in the 20th Century|date=2014|publisher=Taylor and Francis|location=Hoboken|isbn=1135929467|page=470|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m8W2AgAAQBAJ}}</ref> Leplée starred Piaf at the popular Parisian nightspot [[Le Gerny's]] as "La Môme Piaf" (The Little Sparrow).
Leplée was murdered in his apartment in [[Paris]],<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hughes|first1=ed. by Alex|last2=Reader|first2=Keith|title=Encyclopedia of contemporary French culture|date=1998|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=0415131863|edition=1. publ.}}</ref> on April 6, 1936 a day before his 53rd birthday. Piaf was questioned extensively by the police before being cleared of wrongdoing. There has been speculation of mob involvement in Leplée's death.
==In popular culture== He is portrayed by [[Gérard Depardieu]] in the 2007 film ''La Môme'' also known as ''[[La Vie en Rose (film)|La Vie en Rose]]''.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.little-sparrow.co.uk/leplee.htm Little Sparrow web site]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Leplee, Louis}} [[Category:French businesspeople]] [[Category:1883 births]] [[Category:1936 deaths]] [[Category:Nightclub owners]] [[Category:Murdered businesspeople]]
{{France-business-bio-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2017}} {{Use British English|date=August 2017}} [[File:A National Conversation launch.jpg|right|300px|thumb|Scottish First Minister [[Alex Salmond]] and Deputy First Minister [[Nicola Sturgeon]] at the launch of the National Conversation, 14 August 2007]] [[File:AlexSalmond 2007.jpg|thumb|300px|Alex Salmond during a speech at the National Conversation]] The '''National Conversation''' was the name given to the [[Scottish Government]]'s [[public consultation]] exercise regarding possible future changes in the power of the [[devolution|devolved]] [[Scottish Parliament]] and the possibility of [[Scottish independence]], a policy objective of the [[Scottish National Party]], who at the time were the [[minority government]] with power over devolved affairs in [[Scotland]], as the [[Scottish Government]]. It culminated in a multi-option white paper for a proposed [[Referendum (Scotland) Bill, 2010]].
==Process== The National Conversation was launched on 14 August 2007 by [[Alex Salmond]], the [[First Minister of Scotland]]. It consisted of a 59-page [[white paper]], titled [[Choosing Scotland's Future]], and a [[website]]. The white paper included a draft [[bill (proposed law)|bill]] for a [[referendum]] to allow for negotiations with the [[UK Government]] on Scottish independence. The website encourages comments to be made on the white paper. Comments are encouraged from members of the public, rather than just [[interest group]]s.
As a culmination to the National Conversation, a [[white paper]] for the proposed [[Referendum (Scotland) Bill, 2010]] was published on [[St. Andrew's Day]] on 30 November 2009.<ref name=Independent30Nov09SNPReveals>{{cite news |url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/snp-reveals-vision-for-independence-referendum-1831469.html |title = SNP reveals vision for independence referendum |publisher = The Independent |date = 2009-11-30 |accessdate = 2009-11-30 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5lfqjoj1A?url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/snp-reveals-vision-for-independence-referendum-1831469.html |archivedate = 30 November 2009 |location = London |first = Joe |last = Quinn |deadurl = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref name=ScottishGovernment30Nov09NewsYSYV>{{cite web |url = http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2009/11/27154409 |title = Your Scotland, Your Voice |publisher = Scottish Government |work = www.scotland.gov.uk > News > News Releases > 2009 > November > YSYV |date = 2009-11-30 |accessdate = 2009-11-30 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5lfsTqyxt?url=http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2009/11/27154409 |archivedate = 30 November 2009 |deadurl = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref> The 176 page paper was titled, "Your Scotland, Your Voice".<ref name=ScottishGovernmentPDFYourScotlandYourVoice>{{cite web |url = http://www.scotland.gov.uk/Resource/Doc/293639/0090721.pdf |title = Your Scotland, Your Voice |format = PDF |page = 176 |publisher = Scottish Government |date = 2009-11-30 |accessdate = 2009-11-30 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5lfsmWWId?url=http://www.scotland.gov.uk/Resource/Doc/293639/0090721.pdf |archivedate = 30 November 2009 |deadurl = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref> The paper detailed four possible scenarios for Scotland's future, with the text of the Bill and Referendum to be revealed later.<ref name=Independent30Nov09SNPReveals/> The scenarios were: No Change, Devolution per the Calman Review, Full Devolution, and Full Independence.<ref name=Independent30Nov09SNPReveals/>
==Response== On 6 December 2007, the [[Scottish Parliament]] voted to create a [[Commission on Scottish Devolution]], chaired by Sir [[Kenneth Calman]], and with the remit:
: To review the provisions of the Scotland Act 1998 in the light of experience and to recommend any changes to the present constitutional arrangements that would enable the Scottish Parliament to serve the people of Scotland better, improve the financial accountability of the Scottish Parliament, and continue to secure the position of Scotland within the United Kingdom.
The Commission was supported by the three main [[Unionism in Scotland|pro-Union]] political parties in Scotland: [[Scottish Labour Party|Labour]], [[Scottish Conservative Party|Conservatives]] and [[Scottish Liberal Democrats|Liberal Democrats]]. Wendy Alexander, at the time leader of the Labour party in the Scottish Parliament, proposed the motion, rejecting the National Conversation and an amendment proposed by the [[Scottish National Party]] calling for support for the National Conversation was defeated, Ms Alexander associating it with moves towards [[Scottish independence]] and making the following response:
: The SNP amendment predictably calls for us to participate in the National Conversation, but how can the SNP possibly claim to be leading a conversation when it has already decided what the only acceptable outcome will be? Worst of all, it has no parliamentary mandate whatsoever for the conversation. How can the SNP possibly justify the use of taxpayers' money on something that is little more than propaganda?<ref>[http://www.scottish.parliament.uk/parliamentarybusiness.aspx#Col4133 Parliamentary Business : Scottish Parliament<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Notably the remit of the Commission on Scottish Devolution precludes the consideration of Scottish independence.
The rejection of the National Conversation by the Scottish Parliament has led to criticisms as to its legitimacy.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/columnists/alancochrane/3554991/Alex-Salmonds-national-conversation.html | work=The Daily Telegraph | location=London | title=Alex Salmond's national conversation | first=Alan | last=Cochrane | date=2008-02-14 | accessdate=2010-05-19}}</ref> Concerns have also been raised by
===Website controversy===
On 24 April 2008, [[George Foulkes, Baron Foulkes of Cumnock|Lord Foulkes]], a Labour [[Member of the Scottish Parliament]], claimed that the National Conversation had been met with "complete indifference" by the people of Scotland, quoting website visiting figures. He further claimed that the website had become a meeting place for SNP activists, noting also that although 41 comments had been removed from the site, "there are still [[Anglophobia|anti-English]] remarks bordering on [[racism]]."<ref>[http://www.scotsman.com/news/scotland/top-stories/snp-s-national-conversation-a-chatroom-for-cybernats-1-1165459 SNP's national conversation 'a chatroom for cybernats' - The Scotsman<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
== Influence ==
The initiative influenced the [[Parti Québécois]]{{Citation needed|date=October 2008}} and, in March 2008, shortly before the Parti Québécois National Council, leader [[Pauline Marois]] presented the party's plan to propose a ''conversation nationale'' to Quebecers as part of Marois' renewal of the party's approach on independence and [[social democracy]]. In this case, however, the conversation is to be solely on independence, instead of three options. The expression was met with less enthusiasm in [[Quebec]] and arose cynicism in the press and objection with some [[Pur et dur|party hardliners]].<ref>''[https://www.ledevoir.com/2008/03/25/181983.html Logique impériale]'' by François Brousseau, 25 March 2008, ''[[Le Devoir]]'' {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080413132628/http://www.ledevoir.com/2008/03/25/181983.html |date=13 April 2008 }}</ref> Shortly after, the Parti Québécois replaced the term with ''débat sur la souveraineté'' ("debate on [[sovereignty]]").
== See also == * [[Choosing Scotland's Future]] * [[Independence referendum]] * [[Public consultation]] * [[Scottish referendum bill 2010]]
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.scotland.gov.uk/Topics/constitution/a-national-conversation The National Conversation website]
{{Scottish independence referendum, 2014}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox video game | title = Omerta – City of Gangsters | image = Omerta cover.jpg | developer = [[Haemimont Games]] | publisher = [[Kalypso Media]] | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]]
[[Mac OS X]]
[[Xbox 360]] | released = '''Windows, Xbox 360'''
{{vgrelease|GER|31 January 2013{{cite web |url=http://forum.kalypsomedia.com/showthread.php?tid=17579 |title="Omerta - City of Gangsters" - Official Release Dates |last1=Official forum moderator |first1="Melbourne" |date=10 January 2013 |work=Official forum |publisher=[[Kalypso Media]] |accessdate=10 January 2013}}|EU|1 February 2013{{cite web|url=http://forum.kalypsomedia.com/showthread.php?tid=17927 |title=New Trailer Celebrates the Launch of "Omerta - City of Gangsters" UK and Export Territories |last1=Official forum moderator |first1="Melbourne" |date=1 February 2013 |work=Official forum |publisher=[[Kalypso Media]] |accessdate=2 February 2013}}|NA|12 February 2013}}'''Mac OS X'''
2 August 2013{{cite web |url=http://forum.kalypsomedia.com/showthread.php?tid=17557 |title="Omerta - City of Gangsters" Coming to Mac |last1=Official forum moderator |first1="Melbourne" |date=9 January 2013 |work=Official forum |publisher=[[Kalypso Media]] |accessdate=10 January 2013 |quote=Kalypso […] is targeting an early 2013 release on the Mac App Store.}} | genre = [[Simulation game]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer]] }} '''''Omerta – City of Gangsters''''' is a [[simulation game]] with [[Turn-based tactics|turn-based tactical]] game-play elements developed by [[Haemimont Games]] and published by [[Kalypso Media]] for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Mac OS X]] and the [[Xbox 360]]. The game was released in [[German-speaking Europe|German-speaking]] countries on 31 January 2013. The international German download version for Windows was released through the [[Steam (software)|Steam-service]] as well. The English version was released just a day after in the rest of Europe whereas the version for the US market was released on 12 February. A version for Mac OS X was published on 2 August 2013. == Plot == The title covers the time of the 1920s - the [[Roaring Twenties]] - at the time of the [[Prohibition in the United States]]. The game's story takes place in [[Atlantic City, New Jersey|Atlantic City]], [[Atlantic County, New Jersey|Atlantic County]] where, due to the ban of any alcohol in this era, Mafia organizations were able to become powerful off the back of the illegal [[speakeasy]]s. In a time where criminal [[gang]]s rule the city and a handful of morally-questionable men were able to succeed through illegal gambling, high-strength spirits and shady machinations, the player's storyline takes place as the main character creates his empire in this melting pot of illegality. Boss D'Angelo is an immigrant who was born in a small village in [[Sicily]] and has just arrived in [[Atlantic City]]. He has to work his way up the ladder through the [[Mafia: The City of Lost Heaven|Mafia]]-like world. Working his way up from nothing, He must establish himself in the criminal underworld by buying and raiding businesses and attacking rivals, all the while simultaneously fulfilling his version of the [[American dream]]. ==Story== Arriving at Atlantic City, Boss D'Angelo begins his foothold on the criminal empire as he makes money off the prohibition and gambling trade. Sending money back to his brother, he keeps his status as a mob boss secret from him as he works for Louie, a Capo under the eye of Danny Corsini, the leader of the Mafia in Atlantic City. His enemies ranges from independent gangsters to the [[Ku Klux Klan]], which is at bitter odds with the growing immigration problem. Eventually tired of working for Louie, he was sent to perform one last job which was revealed to be a trap, as Danny Corsini was the intended target. The Boss thwarts the assassination and becomes a Capo under Corsini. Expanding his criminal empire eventually allows his brother to come to Atlantic City but not as a brother in crime an [[FBI]] Agent in New York. When the Boss' attempts to set up a source of income through the gambling/nightclub trade draw suspicion to him, Danny Corsini attempts to defend him killing his brother. Forced to turn on Corsini, the Boss emerges victorious. Knowing that his position is fragile, he attempts to unite the Jewish Gangs and Irish Mob in an alliance only for it to be attacked by the KKK. With the D'Angelo mob as the sole survivor of the struggle, the Boss is named Capo de Tutti. He later earns money through real estate and by supporting Mr. Smith as mayor which gives him great influence in the city, upon reaching Michigan Ave his brother offers one last chance for the Boss to come clean, the Boss rejects the idea of selling his men out and eliminates the witnesses who planned to rat out the boss. The Boss came out clean and triumphant and made amends with his brother and owns a private island which he calls Nova Sicilia and his brother left the agency to pursue his dream of being a shipwright and vowed to never speak of their days in the prohibition again. '''The Japanese Incentive''' Somewhere in between the meeting of his brother and the death of Louie Castaneda, Boss D'Angelo receives a lucrative offer from a Japanese Yakuza Hikaro Eda and Fritz, a backer who wanted to help Eda exert his influence into America as laws back then prohibited Asians from owning property. There he meets the beautiful Mikoto Mori, the trophy wife of the Yakuza boss. Little did the boss know, she has a personal vendetta against Hikaro and the Boss now is caught in between love for the woman and the wrath of a powerful man. The story begins with Karl Fritz who approaches the Boss with a deal from Hikaro Eda, an influential Japanese man who had him muscle into McGyure Clan's turf and quickly proves his worth to Hikaro and was tasked with a smuggling job from him. Upon preventing the McGyure Clan from destroying the cargo did he realize what was he smuggling, his wife Kumiko Mori. Angered by the McGyure's attempt at murdering her he personally wipes out the clan and earns a promising alliance with the Yakuza. When Hikaro and his men were attacked at a Cherry Blossom festival by members of the Ku Klux Klan did Hikaro sent him to find who tried to kill him and the Boss learned that Hikaro's own wife was the culprit. Sickened by this senseless conflict he tries to run off with her in an attempt to escape from the criminal underworld only to be dragged down by Hikaro when he tries to kill them both. Then she reveals her past, her family's lands was taken away by Eda and her sister was killed by Hikaro and she was forced to become the bride and assassin of Hikaro. They both work together to take down Eda and eventually have feelings for one another but the heist on Eda's personal assets goes awry when Mikoto goes off to try and kill Eda only to die in the process, in a fit of rage the Boss personally attacks Eda and gets his revenge for Mikoto as he bitterly says that she was the first and last woman he had ever truly loved. === Trivia === Omerta, the game's title, refers to the infamous [[honor code]] called ''"[[Omertà]]"'', a ''"[[Code of silence]]"'' which binds members of the [[Sicilian Mafia|Mafia]] or similar criminal organizations to professional discretion against any third parties. Upon the official retail-release of the boxed- and digital distributed version, the game was also simultaneously released on [[GOG.com]] without any [[copy-protection]], nor other [[digital rights management]] restrictions.{{cite web |publisher=[[GOG.com|GoG.com]] |title='Omerta - City of Gangsters' on ''Good Old Games''|url=http://www.gog.com/gamecard/omerta_city_of_gangsters |date=2013-01-31 |access-date=2013-01-31}} == Gameplay == Beginning with small deals, the player gradually expands his criminal career, eventually advancing highly enough to establish his own business. The player can purchase untenanted shops, buildings and structures to establish his own bar, brewery or distillery. The player can also buy out an opposing ''speakeasy''. A more legal way for generating income is buying apartments to obtain leasing. Warehouses can be acquired to extend storage. As the game progresses, the character can recruit companions, create his own gang, and conquer the territories of rival gangsters. Characters provide specific [[Role-playing game system|role-playing elements]] based on their individual characteristics and equipment. In these [[Turn-based strategy|turn-based]] confrontations, the player expands his influence by using henchmen to drive other godfathers out of business, to ultimately reign supreme as the unchallenged patron of Atlantic City.{{cite web |url=http://forum.kalypsomedia.com/showthread.php?tid=13774 |title=Guns, Money, Honor - Kalypso Unveils "Omerta – City of {{Sic|nolink=y|Gang|ters|expected=Gangsters}}" |last1=Official forum moderator |first1="Melbourne" |date=6 March 2012 |work=Official forum |publisher=[[Kalypso Media]] |accessdate=14 May 2012}} In addition to co-operative and competitive multiplayer game-play, the game offers a [[Open-ended (gameplay)#Sandbox mode|sandbox mode]] to freely explore the game world – six district maps covering ''Atlantic City''. === Historical background === [[File:Traymore1930.jpg|thumb|250px|right|The renowned Traymore Hotel in Atlantic City, circa 1930]] The game provides an explorable three-dimensional world which is displayed through a [[Video game graphics#Top-down perspective|Top-down perspective]]. The in-game world represents, according to the publisher Kalypso Media,{{cite web |url=http://forum.kalypsomedia.com/showthread.php?tid=16677 |title=New Images from "Omerta – City of Gangsters" (Buildings)|last1=Official forum moderator |first1="Melbourne" |date=25 September 2012 |work=Official forum |publisher=[[Kalypso Media]] |accessdate=31 January 2012}} an almost accurate and historical correct reproduction of the American city ''Atlantic City'' of this period. Real vintage buildings and places are present like the [[Traymore Hotel]], the [[Absecon Light]]house, the ''Atlantic City Jail-house'' or the board-walk "Eastern Promenade" as well as streets like ''Illinois Avenue'' or the ''North Carolina Avenue'' which ends at the beach. Beside those real buildings the remaining ones - which are shown in [[Art Deco]] - are very similar to each other and seems to consist only of a few types. == Licensing of name == Kalypso Media licensed the name 'Omerta' from the [[MMORPG]] browser based game of the same name, [[Omerta (video game)|Omerta]]. == Reception == [[Metacritic]] aggregated a score of 54 from 100 points for the Windows version.{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/omerta-city-of-gangsters |title=Omerta: City of Gangsters for PC Reviews, Ratings, Credits, and More - Metacritic |author= |authorlink=Metacritic |date=31 January 2013 |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=5 February 2012}} ''PCGamer'' gave the PC-version a rating of 78 out of 100 points, praising the game's mechanics as well as the [[Artificial intelligence (video games)|AI]] while comparing its combat style elements to [[X-COM]] or [[Jagged Alliance]]. The story is described as too superficial and simple, just depth-less. The atmospheric music, on the other hand, was lauded as a brilliant melange of the [[Jazz]], [[Ragtime]] and [[Klezmer]] music of the period. {{Quote|'''"Not as tough or as deep as it could be, Omerta is still a destination well worth a visit."'''|Tim Stone|PCGamer.com{{cite web |url=http://www.pcgamer.com/review/omerta-city-of-gangsters-review/ |title=Omerta: City of Gangsters review |last=Stone |first=Tim |date=January 31, 2013 |work=Review |publisher=[[PC Gamer]] |accessdate=February 2, 2012}}}} Rating the game at just 30 percent, ''Metro GameCentral'' tested the PC-version as well. Initially intrigued by the promise of a new kind of "made-men" game, the turn-based combat system was ultimately deemed ungainly. {{Quote|'''"You can see the basis of a good game here but Omerta gets almost everything wrong, from the shallow game-play to the bland, characterless gangster atmosphere."'''|Roger Hargreaves|GameCentral|Metro.co.uk{{cite web |url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/02/04/omerta-city-of-gangsters-review-refuse-the-offer-3379811/ |title=Omerta: City Of Gangsters review – refuse the offer |last=Hargreaves |first=Roger |date=February 4, 2013 |work=Review |publisher=GameCentral|Metro.co.uk |accessdate=February 5, 2012}}}} ''Hooked Gamer'' gave the PC-version a rating of 8.4 out of 10. It describes the game as "different", and the turn-based combats as short but satisfying. {{Quote|'''"What struck me most was the potential. Omerta is a good game but if it succeeds, it has the potential to be a great game. […]"'''|Sergio Brinkhuis|Hooked Gamers{{cite web |url=http://www.hookedgamers.com/pc/omerta_city_of_gangsters/review/article-1017-2.html |title=Omerta: City of Gangsters review for PC – Hooked Gamers |last=Brinkhuis |first=Sergio |date=January 31, 2013 |work=Review |publisher=HookedGamers |accessdate=February 4, 2013}}}} == References == {{Reflist|2|refs= }} == External links == * [http://www.cityofgangsters.com/ Official games website] * [http://orcz.com/Category:Omerta_City_of_Gangsters Omerta - City of Gangsters (inoff. Wiki)] * [http://www.gog.com/gamecard/omerta_city_of_gangsters Omerta - City of Gangsters on [[GOG.com|GoG.com]]] (digital Download) {{Haemimont}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Omerta - City of Gangsters}} [[Category:2013 video games]] [[Category:Business simulation games]] [[Category:MacOS games]] [[Category:Organized crime video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Bulgaria]] [[Category:Video games set in the 1920s]] [[Category:Video games set in the United States]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Xbox 360 games]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox NRHP | name =Shot Tower | nrhp_type = nhl | image = Phoenix Shot Tower.png | caption = Phoenix Shot Tower | location= [[Baltimore, Maryland]] | coordinates = {{coord|39|17|26|N|76|36|20|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = United States Baltimore#Maryland#USA | area = | built =1828 | architect= Unknown | architecture= | designated_nrhp_type = November 11, 1971<ref name="nhlsum">{{cite web|url=http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=878&ResourceType=Structure|title=Phoenix Shot Tower|accessdate=2009-03-30|work=National Historic Landmark summary listing|publisher=National Park Service|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090309084709/http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=878&ResourceType=Structure|archivedate=2009-03-09|df=}}</ref> | added = October 1, 1969 | governing_body = Local | refnum=69000373<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|2007a}}</ref> }}
The '''Phoenix Shot Tower''', also known as the '''Old Baltimore Shot Tower''', is a red brick [[shot tower]], {{convert|234.25|ft|m}} tall, located near the [[downtown Baltimore|downtown]], [[Jonestown, Baltimore|Jonestown]] (also known later as Old Town), and [[Little Italy, Baltimore|Little Italy]] communities of East [[Baltimore]], in [[Maryland]]. When it was completed in 1828 it was the tallest structure in the [[United States]].
The tower was originally known as the "Phoenix Shot Tower", then the "Merchants' Shot Tower", and now is also sometimes called the "Old Baltimore Shot Tower".<ref name="NPS-b29"/> It is the only surviving shot tower among three that existed in Baltimore,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://msa.maryland.gov/megafile/msa/speccol/sc4300/sc4300/000005/000000/000003/unrestricted/baltimore_county_mills.pdf |title= Baltimore City and County Mills A-C |accessdate= June 8, 2017}}</ref> and was designated a [[National Historic Landmark]] on November 11, 1971.<ref name="nhlsum"/> It was designated as a local Baltimore City Landmark on October 14, 1975.<ref>Baltimore City Commission on Historical and Architectural Preservation, "Baltimore City’s Designated Landmark List", July 2012.
https://chap.baltimorecity.gov/sites/default/files/Baltimore%20City%20Landmarks%20publication.pdf</ref>
The Shot Tower lends its name to the nearby [[Shot Tower/Market Place (Metro Subway station)|Shot Tower/Market Place station]] on the [[Metro Subway (Baltimore)|Baltimore Metro subway system]]'s northeast line. Additionally, the original [[Baltimore Bullets (1944–54)|Baltimore Bullets]] were named in honor of its role in producing shot.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Vecsey|first1=George|title=Sports of The Times;Say Goodbye To 'Bullets' As Nickname|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/12/sports/sports-of-the-times-say-goodbye-to-bullets-as-nickname.html|website=The New York Times|accessdate=28 January 2018|date=12 November 1995}}</ref>
== Design== The tower was built by Jacob Wolfe<ref name="JHU-engineer">[http://www.ce.jhu.edu/baltimorestructures/Shot%20Tower/shot_tower.htm "An Engineer's Guide to Baltimore: Phoenix Shot Tower"], accessed May 6, 2007 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070311042830/http://www.ce.jhu.edu/baltimorestructures/Shot+Tower/shot_tower.htm |date=March 11, 2007 }}</ref> using bricks manufactured by the Burns and Russell Company of Baltimore. [[Charles Carroll of Carrollton]], the last surviving signer of the [[United States Declaration of Independence|Declaration of Independence]], a Roman Catholic lay leader and wealthiest man in America at that time, laid its cornerstone.<ref>https://www.nps.gov/nr/travel/baltimore/b29.htm</ref>
The circular brick structure's walls are {{convert|4.5|ft|m}} thick from the bottom to about {{convert|50|ft|m}} up; then they narrow in stages of {{convert|4|in|cm}} each, until reaching a thickness of {{convert|21|in|cm}} at the top.<ref name="JHU-engineer"/><ref name="nrhpinv1">{{cite web|url={{NHLS url|id=69000373}}|title=National Register of Historic Places Inventory Nomination: Baltimore Shot Tower|last=Morton|first=W. Brown III|date=July 30, 1971|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2009-03-30}}</ref>
==Production== {{details|topic=this process|Shot tower}} Molten [[lead]] was dropped from a platform at the top of the tower, through a sieve-like device, into a vat of cold water at the bottom of the tower<ref name="NPS-b29">[http://www.cr.nps.gov/nr/travel/baltimore/b29.htm "Shot Tower"], National Park Service, accessed May 6, 2007</ref> to produce both "drop shot" for pistols and rifles and "moulded shot" for larger weapons such as cannons.<ref name="NPS-baltoshot">[http://www.cr.nps.gov/hps/pad/adventure/baltoshot.htm "Baltimore (Phoenix) Shot Tower"], National Park Service, accessed May 6, 2007</ref> When hardened, dried, and polished, the shot was sorted into 25-pound bags. The annual production was about 100,000 bags of shot a year,<ref name="NPS-SS">[http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=878&ResourceType=Structure Statement of Significance] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090309084709/http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=878&ResourceType=Structure |date=2009-03-09 }} at the [[National Park Service]]'s [[National Historic Landmark|National Historic Landmark Program]] website, accessed May 6, 2007</ref> with the capability of doubling that in case of war or other high demand.<ref name="NPS-b29"/>
The tower stopped producing shot in 1892,<ref name="JHU-engineer"/> when a new method of making shot made the tower obsolete. It re-opened for a brief period of production at the beginning of the twentieth century, and then closed for good.<ref name="CM">[http://www.carrollmuseums.org/pages/3/index.htm Phoenix Shot Tower''], Carroll Museums, accessed May 6, 2007</ref>
== History == The tower remained the [[List of tallest buildings in the United States|tallest structure in the United States]] until 1846, when [[Trinity Church, New York]] on [[Wall Street]] was erected, and the [[List of tallest buildings in Baltimore|tallest in Baltimore]] until the completion of the spire of the [[First Presbyterian Church and Manse (Baltimore, Maryland)|First Presbyterian Church]] at West Madison Street and Park Avenue in the [[Mount Vernon, Baltimore|Mount Vernon-Belvedere]] neighborhood in 1875. [[File:Behind the Scenes Tour of the Phoenix Shot Tower (6280561056).jpg|thumb|left|Interior of the tower, looking down]]
The shot tower was originally owned by the Merchants' Shot Tower Company which closed in 1898.<ref name="NPS-baltoshot"/>
In 1921 the tower was purchased for $14,500 by the [[Union Oil Company]], which planned to tear it down and put a [[filling station|gas station]] in its place. After strong objections by the community, by 1928 enough money had been raised to purchase the tower and present it to the City of Baltimore as one of its first preserved local historic landmarks.<ref name="JHU-engineer"/> [[File:Phoenix Shot Tower 04.jpg|thumb|Plaques at the Phoenix Shot Tower, formerly the Merchants Shot Tower, in Baltimore's Jonestown neighborhood]] The tower was designated a [[National Historic Landmark]] in 1971 and a bronze plaque was attached to the tower's brick wall at the base. In the early 1980s, the management, exhibits, and tours were combined with those of the former [[Peale Museum]]. In 1985, other historic sites and homes were added to the newly created Baltimore City Life Museums system. The BCLM was closed in 1997, and in 2002 Carroll Museums, Inc was created to manage both the [[Carroll Mansion]] and the Shot Tower.<ref name=CM />
==External links== * [http://www.carrollmuseums.org/ Phoenix Shot Tower] - web page by Carroll Museums, the organization that maintains the tower as a museum *[http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/travel/baltimore/index.htm Baltimore, Maryland, a National Park Service ''Discover Our Shared Heritage'' Travel Itinerary] *[https://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&geocode=&q=phoenix+shot+tower&sll=37.0625,-95.677068&sspn=33.572881,60.46875&ie=UTF8&ll=39.290817,-76.605928&spn=0.008005,0.014763&z=16&iwloc=addr&layer=c&cbll=39.290779,-76.606064&panoid=N4ARw9UO3rZNi_vNdJygDw&cbp=12,102.25225550476045,,0,-24.825581395348827 Phoenix Shot Tower on Google Street View] *[http://explore.baltimoreheritage.org/items/show/200 Explore Baltimore Heritage - Phoenix Shot Tower] *[http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/hhh.md0141 Phoenix Shot Tower, Front & Fayette Streets, Baltimore, Independent City, MD] at the [[Historic American Buildings Survey]] (HABS) *{{MHT url|id=80|title=Shot Tower, Baltimore City}}, including undated photo, at Maryland Historical Trust
== References == {{commons category}} {{reflist|33em}}

revision.text: {{globalize|2=Costa Rica|3=Europe|4=USA|4name=the United States|date=August 2015}} A '''public-sector trade union''' (or '''public-sector labor union''') is a [[trade union]] which primarily represents the interests of employees within [[public sector]] or governmental organizations. ==History and recent developments== ===Costa Rica=== {{Main|Trade unions in Costa Rica}} In the late 1800s, trade unions first appeared to support workers in a variety of urban and industrial jobs.{{cite web|title=Historia del Sindicalismo|url=http://sitrapequia.or.cr/gestor/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=52|work=SITRAPEQUIA website|publisher=Sindicato de Trabajadores(as) Petroléros Químicos y Afines|accessdate=4 May 2014|location=San José|language=es|year=2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140505020834/http://sitrapequia.or.cr/gestor/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=52|archivedate=5 May 2014|df=}} After facing violent repression, such as during the 1934 United Fruit Strike, unions gained more power following the 1948 [[Costa Rican Civil War]], and public sector unions appeared. Previous administrations and assesmblies paid very little attention to Costa Rica's trade unions;,{{cite news|last1=Sequeira|first1=Aarón|title=Sindicalismo gana voces en el Congreso e impulsa su agenda|url=http://www.nacion.com/nacional/politica/Sindicalismo-voces-Congreso-impulsa-agenda_0_1418258197.html|accessdate=2 June 2014|publisher=La Nacion|date=2 June 2014|location=San Jose|language=Es}} however when the [[Luis Guillermo Solís]] and the 2014 legislative assembly took office, Solís and eight members of the [[Citizens' Action Party (Costa Rica)|Citizens' Action Party]] and [[Broad Front (Costa Rica)|Broad Front]] promised to listen to unions. Libertarian [[Otto Guevara]] expressed concern. Today, Costa Rican unions are strongest in the public sector, including the fields of education and medicine. There is also a strong presence in agricultural sectors for unions. In general, Costa Rican unions support government regulation of the banking, medical, and education fields, as well as improved wages and working conditions.{{cite news|last=Herrera|first=Manuel|title=Sindicatos alzarán la voz contra modelo neoliberal en celebraciones del 1° de mayo|url=http://www.nacion.com/nacional/trabajo/Sindicatos-alzaran-modelo-neoliberal-celebraciones_0_1411658998.html|accessdate=7 May 2014|newspaper=La Nacion|date=30 April 2014|location=San Jose|language=es}} One important issue for public sector unions is passage of the Código Procesal Laboral (Procedural Labor Law), which former president [[Laura Chinchilla]] vetoed.{{cite news|last=Sequeira|first=Aarón|title=Presidente del Congreso se reúne con sindicatos y promete cambios al Código de Trabajo|url=http://www.nacion.com/nacional/politica/Presidente-Congreso-sindicatos-Codigo-Trabajo_0_1412058926.html|accessdate=5 May 2014|newspaper=La Nacion|date=2 May 2014|location=San Jose|language=Es}} If passed, Chinchilla said it would allow emergency service workers, such as police, medical service staff and doctors to strike. President [[Luis Guillermo Solís]] said that the issue of the Procedural Labor Law should be finalized within his first year in office.{{cite news|last=Oveido|first=Estaban|title=Luis Guillermo Solís avala plazo de un año para resolver veto a reforma laboral|url=http://www.nacion.com/nacional/politica/Luis-Guillermo-Solis-resolver-reforma_0_1412858729.html|accessdate=6 May 2014|newspaper=La Nacion|date=6 May 2014|location=San Jose|language=Es}} [[Legislative Assembly of Costa Rica|Legislative Assembly]] president [[Henry Mora Jiménez]], also supported the law, as do the public sector unions. ===Europe=== There are public-sector trade unions in Europe that negotiate agreements between public employees and the institutions for which they work. In 2010, severe financial crises forced several governments to cut back on wages and benefits in austerity measures, leading to protests, most notably in Greece. In Greece, a one-day protest was held because of requirements placed by the EU on Greece's public spending.See "Greece hit by nationwide strike over austerity" [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8507551.stm BBC News 10 February 2010] ===United States=== {{main|Public-sector trade unions in the United States}} Labor unions generally bypassed government employees because they were controlled mostly by the patronage system used by the political parties before the arrival of civil service. Post Office workers did form unions. The [[National Association of Letter Carriers]] started in 1889 and grew quickly. By the mid-1960s it had 175,000 members in 6,400 local branches.{{cite book|author=Morris S. Ogul|title=Congress Oversees the Bureaucracy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MxHpmVLxj1kC&pg=PA65|date=15 May 1976|publisher=U. of Pittsburgh Press|page=65}} Several competing organizations of postal clerks emerged starting in the 1890s. Merger discussions dragged on for years, until finally the NFPOC, UNMAPOC and others merged in 1961 as the United Federation of Postal Clerks. Another round of mergers in 1971 produced the [[American Postal Workers Union]] (APWU). In 2012 the APWU had 330,000 members.Gary M Fink, ed., ''Labor Unions'' (1977) pp 291-94 The various postal unions did not engage in strikes. {{main|Boston Police Strike}} Historian Joseph Slater, says, "Unfortunately for public sector unions, the most searing and enduring image of their history in the first half of the twentieth century was the Boston police strike. The strike was routinely cited by courts and officials through the end of the 1940s."Joseph Slater, "The Boston Police Strike'' in Aaron Brenner et al. eds. ''The Encyclopedia of Strikes in American History'' (2011) [https://books.google.com/books?id=EHzk54IjNpEC&pg=PA241] Governor [[Calvin Coolidge]] broke the strike and the legislature took control of the police away from city officials.Francis Russell, ''A city in terror: Calvin Coolidge and the 1919 Boston police strike'' (Beacon Press, 1975) The police strike chilled union interest in the public sector in the 1920s. The major exception was the emergence of unions of public school teachers in the largest cities; they formed the [[American Federation of Teachers]] (AFT), affiliated with the AFL. In suburbs and small cities, the [[National Education Association]] (NEA) became active, but it insisted it was not a labor union but a professional organization.Marjorie Murphy, ''Blackboard Unions: The AFT and the NEA, 1900-1980'' (1992) ====New Deal era==== In the mid 1930s efforts were made to unionize WPA workers, but were opposed by President Franklin D. Roosevelt.Chad Alan Goldberg, "Contesting the Status of Relief Workers during the New Deal The Workers Alliance of America and the Works Progress Administration, 1935-1941." ''Social Science History'' (2005) 29#3 pp: 337-371. Moe points out that Roosevelt, "an ardent supporter of collective bargaining in the private sector, was opposed to it in the public sector."{{cite book|author=Moe|title=Special Interest: Teachers Unions and America's Public Schools|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lDFz6oYRtuIC&pg=PA33|year=2011|page=33}} Roosevelt in 1937 told the nation what the position of his government was: "All Government employees should realize that the process of collective bargaining, as usually understood, cannot be transplanted into the public service.... The very nature and purposes of government make it impossible for administrative officials to represent fully or to bind the employer in mutual discussions with government employee organizations.see [http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=15445#axzz1Jy35UQb9 "Letter on the Resolution of Federation of Federal Employees Against Strikes in Federal Service August 16, 1937"] ===="Little New Deal" era==== Change came in the 1950s. In 1958 New York mayor [[Robert Wagner, Jr.]] issued an executive order, called "the little Wagner Act," giving city employees certain bargaining rights, and gave their unions with exclusive representation (that is, the unions alone were legally authorized to speak for all city workers, regardless of whether or not some workers were members.) Management complained but the unions had power in city politics.Anthony C. Russo, "Management's View of the New York City Experience," ''Proceedings of the Academy of Political Science'' Vol. 30, No. 2, "Unionization of Municipal Employees" (Dec., 1970), pp. 81-93 [https://www.jstor.org/stable/1173366 in JSTOR] By the 1960s and 1970s public-sector unions expanded rapidly to cover teachers, clerks, firemen, police, prison guards and others. In 1962, President [[John Kennedy]] issued [[Executive Order 10988]], upgrading the status of unions of federal workers.David Schultz, ''Encyclopedia of public administration and public policy'' (2004) p. 143 ====Recent years==== After 1960 public sector unions grew rapidly and secured good wages and high pensions for their members. While manufacturing and farming steadily declined, state- and local-government employment quadrupled from 4 million workers in 1950 to 12 million in 1976 and 16.6 million in 2009.U.S. Census Bureau, [https://www.census.gov/newsroom/releases/archives/governments/cb10-132.html "Census Bureau Reports State and Local Government Employment Remains at 16.6 Million" (press release Aug. 10, 2010)] In 2009 the U.S. membership of public sector unions surpassed membership of private sector unions for the first time, at 7.9m and 7.4m respectively.http://www.nationalaffairs.com/publications/detail/the-trouble-with-public-sector-unions In 2011 states faced a growing fiscal crisis and the Republicans had made major gains in the 2010 elections. Public sector unions came under heavy attack [[2011 Wisconsin budget protests|especially in Wisconsin]], as well as Indiana, New Jersey and Ohio from conservative Republican legislatures.John Logan, "Is this the end for organised labour in the US?," [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/cifamerica/2011/mar/11/us-unions-wisconsin guardian.co.uk, March 11, 2011]see [https://www.nytimes.com/roomfordebate/2011/02/18/the-first-blow-against-public-employees "Public employees"] 2012 update.see [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/special/politics/state-budget-crisis/index.html "Budget crisis"] Conservative state legislatures tried to drastically reduce the abilities of unions to collectively bargain. Conservatives argued that public unions were too powerful since they helped elect their bosses, and that overly generous pension systems were too heavy a drain on state budgets.{{cite book|author1=Theda Skocpol|author2=Vanessa Williamson|title=The Tea Party and the Remaking of Republican Conservatism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Gm56Pg3um2IC&pg=PA192|year=2012|publisher=Oxford UP|page=192}} ==See also== * [[International comparisons of labor unions]] * [[Public-sector trade unions in the United States]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * Bach, Stephen, et al., eds. ''Public service employment relations in Europe: transformation, modernization or inertia?'' (Routledge, 2005) * Carter, Bob, and Peter Fairbrother. "The transformation of British public-sector industrial relations: from ‘model employer’to marketized relations." ''Historical Studies in Industrial Relations'' 7 (1999): 119-146. * Cheung, Anthony, and Ian Scott, eds. ''Governance and Public Sector Reform in Asia: Paradigm Shift or Business as Usual?'' (Routledge, 2012) * Garrett, Geoffrey, and Christopher Way. "Public sector unions, corporatism, and macroeconomic performance." ''Comparative Political Studies'' 32.4 (1999): 411-434. * Gregory, Robert G., and Jeff Borland. "Recent developments in public sector labor markets" in ''Handbook of labor economics'' 3 (1999): 3573-3630. * Lamo, Ana, Javier J. Pérez, and Ludger Schuknecht. "Public or Private Sector Wage Leadership? An International Perspective," ''Scandinavian Journal of Economics'' 114.1 (2012): 228-244. [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1467-9442.2011.01665.x/full online] * Lucifora, Claudio, and Dominique Meurs. "The public sector pay gap in France, Great Britain and Italy." ''Review of Income and Wealth'' 52.1 (2006): 43-59. * Terry, Mike, ed. ''Redefining Public Sector Unionism: UNISON and the future of trade unions'' Routledge, 2012. * Visser, Jelle. "Union membership statistics in 24 countries." ''Monthly Labor Review'' 129 (2006): 38. {{Organized labor}} [[Category:Trade unions]] [[Category:Labor relations]] [[Category:Public sector trade unions| ]]

{{refimprove|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox newspaper | name = Puget Sound Business Journal | logo = | image = | caption = | type = Weekly newspaper | format = | owners = [[American City Business Journals]] | founder = | publisher = | editor = | president = | chiefeditor = | assoceditor = | maneditor = | newseditor = | managingeditordesign = | campuseditor = | campuschief = | opeditor = | sportseditor = | photoeditor = | staff = | foundation = | political = | language = English | ceased publication = | relaunched = | headquarters = 800 1st Avenue
[[Seattle]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]] | circulation = 17,919 (December 2013){{cite web |url=http://abcas3.auditedmedia.com/ecirc/magtitlesearch.asp |title= eCirc for Business Publications |date= December 31, 2013 |publisher= [[Alliance for Audited Media]]|accessdate=February 19, 2014}} | sister newspapers = | ISSN = 8750-7757 | oclc = | website = {{URL|http://www.bizjournals.com/seattle/|bizjournals.com/seattle}} | free = | dirinteractive = }} The '''''Puget Sound Business Journal''''' ('''PSBJ''') is a weekly [[American City Business Journals]] publication containing articles about [[business]] people, issues, and events in the greater [[Seattle, Washington]] area. The publication also publishes a technology news website named TechFlash. In 2010, the newspaper was a finalist for a [[Pulitzer Prize]] in Explanatory Reporting for a series of stories about the foreclosure crises and the federal shutdown of Seattle-based [[Washington Mutual]], which remains the biggest bank failure in U.S. history. The stories were reported by staff writers [[Kirsten Grind]] and Jeanne Lang Jones, and edited by Managing Editor [[Alwyn Scott]].{{cite news |last=Anderson |first=Rick |date=April 13, 2010 |title=Biz Journal: A Pulitzer in Effort, at Least |url=http://archive.seattleweekly.com/home/937562-129/media |work=[[Seattle Weekly]] |accessdate=September 1, 2016}} Congressman [[Dave Reichert]] later honored the PSBJ alongside Pulitzer winners ''[[The Seattle Times]]'' during his remarks, praising the former's "inclusive and thorough" reporting as an "invaluable public service".{{cite web |last=Reichert |first=David |authorlink=Dave Reichert |date=April 21, 2010 |title=Honoring The Seattle Times and the Puget Sound Business Journal |url=https://www.congress.gov/congressional-record/2010/4/21/extensions-of-remarks-section/article/E600-5 |work=[[Congressional Record]] |accessdate=September 1, 2016}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.bizjournals.com/seattle/}} *[http://www.techflash.com TechFlash] {{Advance Publications}} [[Category:Newspapers published in Seattle]] [[Category:American business newspapers]] {{Washington-newspaper-stub}}
