{{pp-pc1}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Rodney Frelinghuysen |image = Rodney Frelinghuysen official photo, 114th Congress.jpg |office = Chair of the [[United States House Committee on Appropriations|House Appropriations Committee]] |term_start = January 3, 2017 |term_end = |predecessor = [[Hal Rogers]] |successor = TBD |state1 = [[New Jersey]] |district1 = {{ushr|NJ|11|11th}} |term_start1 = January 3, 1995 |term_end1 = |predecessor1 = [[Dean Gallo]] |successor1 = [[Mikie Sherrill]] {{small|(Elect)}} |state_assembly2 = New Jersey |district2 = 25th |term_start2 = January 10, 1984 |term_end2 = January 3, 1995 |predecessor2 = [[James J. Barry Jr.]] |successor2 = [[Anthony Bucco]] |birth_name = Rodney Procter Frelinghuysen |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1946|4|29}} |birth_place = {{nowrap|[[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S.}} |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |spouse = {{marriage|Virginia Robinson|1980}} |children = 2 |education = [[Hobart and William Smith Colleges|Hobart College]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[Trinity College (Connecticut)|Trinity College, Connecticut]] |website = {{url|frelinghuysen.house.gov|House website}} |allegiance = {{flag|United States}} |branch = {{army|United States}} |serviceyears = 1969–1971 |rank = [[File:E-5 - SPC5.PNG|15px]] [[Specialist (rank)|Specialist 5]]{{cite web |url=http://www.ausa.org/legislation/congressionalinfo/Documents/OAS%20112th%20Congress.pdf|title=Once a Soldier... Always a Soldier |year=2011|work=Legislative Agenda|publisher=[[Association of the United States Army]]|accessdate=January 27, 2013|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021200011/http://www.ausa.org/legislation/congressionalinfo/Documents/OAS%20112th%20Congress.pdf|archivedate=October 21, 2013|df=mdy-all}} |unit = 93rd Engineer Battalion |battles = [[Vietnam War]] }} '''Rodney Procter Frelinghuysen''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|f|r|eɪ|l|ɪ|ŋ|ˌ|h|aɪ|s|ən}}As pronounced in "[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rHb0YPOm3LA Repeal and Replace ACA]". (born April 29, 1946) is the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] for {{ushr|NJ|11}}, serving since 1995. The district includes most of [[Morris County, New Jersey|Morris County]], an affluent suburban county west of [[New York City]]. It also includes some of the wealthier areas near [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]] and [[Paterson, New Jersey|Paterson]], and is the 10th richest congressional district in the nation in terms of median income.{{cite news|last1=Warner|first1=Kelsey|title=Where Are The Richest Voter Districts In The U.S.?|url=https://www.business2community.com/government-politics/richest-voter-districts-u-s-01516219|accessdate=16 January 2018|publisher=Business 2 Community|date=April 14, 2016}} A member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]], Frelinghuysen has served as Chair of the [[United States House Committee on Appropriations|House Appropriations Committee]] since 2017. Frelinghuysen announced on January 29, 2018, that he would not seek re-election that year.{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2018/01/29/politics/rodney-frelinghuysen-retiring/index.html|title=Rep. Rodney Frelinghuysen becomes latest GOP chairman to retire|author=Deirdre Walsh, Lauren Fox and Eric Bradner|date=January 29, 2018 |publisher=CNN}} On domestic issues, he has at times supported abortion rights and at times voted to limit access to abortion,Ed Kilgore, October 3, 2017, New York Magazine, [http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2017/10/house-passes-20-week-abortion-ban-on-party-vote.html House Passes 20-Week Abortion Ban on Near-Perfect Party-Line Vote], Retrieved January 11, 2017 opposed federal funding of [[Planned Parenthood]],Lisa Marie Segarra, March 7, 2017, North Jersey, [https://www.northjersey.com/story/news/politics/2017/03/07/planned-parenthood-brings-rally-frelinghuysens-office/98855028/ Planned Parenthood brings rally to Frelinghuysen's office], Retrieved January 11, 2017, "...the congressman voted to fund Planned Parenthood in 2007, 2009 and 2011, but voted against it from 2015 through 2017...." and opposed [[Sanctuary city|sanctuary cities]],Jonathan D. Salant, June 29, 2017, NJ.com, [http://www.nj.com/politics/index.ssf/2017/06/how_house_republicans_are_trying_to_punish_sanctua.html How Republicans want to punish sanctuary cities (including those in N.J.)], Retrieved January 11, 2017, "..House Republicans, including four from New Jersey, voted Thursday to take away federal funds from municipalities that do not respond to federal requests to detain unauthorized immigrants.... and Rodney Frelinghuysen (R-11th Dist.) all voted in favor of cutting off the federal funding..." gun control, gay marriage, and federal regulation of greenhouse gas emissions.Nancy Solomon, May 29, 2017, New York Times, [https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/29/nyregion/political-winds-leave-new-jersey-lawmaker-caught-between-party-and-home.html?_r=0 Political Winds Leave New Jersey Lawmaker Caught Between Party and Home], Retrieved January 11, 2017, "... Frelinghuysen once supported abortion rights but in recent years has voted to limit access to abortion. He also opposes gun control, gay marriage and regulations to limit greenhouse gas emissions...." He endorsed Donald Trump in the 2016 presidential election.{{Cite news|url=http://www.nj.com/morris/index.ssf/2016/08/morris_dems_call_for_local_republicans_to_pull_sup.html|title=How Trump's comments are being used against Republicans in N.J.|work=NJ.com|accessdate=March 2, 2017}} He voted to repeal the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]] (Obamacare) and replace it with the [[American Health Care Act of 2017|American Health Care Act]] (AHCA). Frelinghuysen was criticized for using a fundraising letter to "[out] a member of an activist group opposing him to her employer" which resulted in a complaint by the [[Campaign for Accountability]] made with the Office of Congressional Ethics.{{cite web|url=http://www.nj.com/morris/index.ssf/2017/05/frelinghuysens_letter_to_activists_employer_sparks.html|title=Frelinghuysen's letter to activist's employer sparks outrage|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/05/16/rodney-frelinghuysen-ethics-complaint-238452|title=Frelinghuysen faces ethics complaint for targeting activist|publisher=}}WN.com, [https://article.wn.com/view/2017/07/13/Frelinghuysen_hires_lawyers_after_ethics_complaint_about_rin/ Frelinghuysen hires lawyers after ethics complaint about 'ringleader' letter], Retrieved January 12, 2017, "...Frelinghuysen paid lawyers in New Jersey and Washington nearly $32,000 this spring after an ethics complaint was filed over a fund-raising letter he sent to a bank official ..." ==Family and early life== Frelinghuysen was born in New York City to [[Peter Frelinghuysen Jr.]], a New Jersey politician and Beatrice Sterling Procter, an heir to the [[Procter & Gamble]] fortune.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/24/nyregion/peter-frelinghuysen-jr-95-longtime-nj-congressman-dies.html|title=Peter Frelinghuysen Jr., 95, Longtime N.J. Congressman, Dies|last=Fried|first=Joseph P.|date=May 23, 2011|work=The New York Times|accessdate=March 2, 2017|issn=0362-4331}} Frelinghuysen is a member of a [[Frelinghuysen family|family long prominent]] in [[New Jersey]] politics, one which was ranked the seventh greatest [[List of United States political families|American political dynasty]] by [[Stephen H. Hess]], senior fellow emeritus at the [[Brookings Institution]], and author of "America's Political Dynasties".{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/09/11/AR2009091101831.html |title=America's Top Dynasty?|last=Hess|first=Stephen|date=September 13, 2009 |accessdate=January 29, 2018 |newspaper=The Washington Post. ''washingtonpost.com''}} His father, [[Peter Frelinghuysen Jr.]], served as the U.S. Representative from [[New Jersey's 5th congressional district]] from 1953–75, representing much of the same area Rodney does today. He is the great-great-grandson of [[Frederick Theodore Frelinghuysen]], who was a U.S. Senator for New Jersey and [[United States Secretary of State|U.S. Secretary of State]] in the administration of President [[Chester A. Arthur]]. His great-great-great-uncle, the adoptive father of Frederick Theodore, [[Theodore Frelinghuysen]] was a U.S. Senator for New Jersey, served as president of both [[New York University]] and [[Rutgers University|Rutgers College]], and was the [[Vice President of the United States|vice-presidential]] running mate of [[Henry Clay]] on the [[Whig Party (United States)|Whig]] ticket in the [[United States presidential election, 1844|presidential election of 1844]]. Frelinghuysen's great-great-great-great-grandfather [[Frederick Frelinghuysen (general)|Frederick Frelinghuysen]] was one of the framers of the first [[Constitution of New Jersey]], a U.S. Senator for New Jersey, and a soldier in the [[American Revolutionary War]].{{cite web|url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~battle/reps/frelinghuysen.htm|title=frelinghuysen|website=Freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com|accessdate=February 22, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160313024936/http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~battle/reps/frelinghuysen.htm|archivedate=March 13, 2016|df=mdy-all}} Aside from the Frelinghuysen name, he is a great-great-great-grandson of [[Peter Ballantine]], founder of [[Ballantine Brewery]] in Newark. On his mother's side, he is a great-great-grandson of [[William Procter (candlemaker)|William Procter]], co-founder of [[Procter & Gamble]].{{dead link|date=January 2018}} He attended [[St. Mark's School (Massachusetts)|St. Mark's School]], an exclusive Episcopal preparatory school in [[Southborough, Massachusetts]].{{cite news|last1=Pearce|first1=Jeremy|title=War And Politesse|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/20/nyregion/war-and-politesse.html|accessdate=4 February 2018|publisher=NY Times|date=April 20, 2003}} Rejected by [[Princeton University|Princeton]],{{cite book|last=Golden|first=Daniel|title=The Price of Admission: How America's Ruling Class Buys Its Way into Elite Colleges – and Who Gets Left Outside the Gates|year=2009|publisher=Random House LLC|isbn=0307497372|page=226|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=o4Xm2vDh_wcC&dq=ruling+class+hobart+college&source=gbs_navlinks_s}} the alma mater of his father and grandfather, Frelinghuysen instead matriculated at [[Hobart and William Smith Colleges|Hobart College]] in New York. There he served as president of the [[Kappa Alpha Society]] and earned a BA in American history in 1969.{{cite web|last=Frelinghuysen|first=Rodney|title=Profiles, '69: Rodney Frelinghuysen|url=http://www.hws.edu/academics/polisci/images/alum_profile.swf|work=Hobart and William Smith Colleges, Political Science Department|publisher=Hobart and William Smith Colleges|accessdate=January 2, 2014}} Frelinghuysen next enrolled in a graduate program at [[Trinity College, Hartford|Trinity College]] but was soon drafted into the [[United States Army]]. Following basic training at [[Fort Dix, New Jersey|Fort Dix]], he was assigned as a clerk to the commanding officer of the 93rd Engineer Battalion, which was primarily responsible for building roads and water supply systems in the [[Mekong Delta]] of [[Vietnam War|Vietnam]].{{cite web|title=Congressman and His Army Commander Reunite During ABA Day After 42 Years|url=http://www.abanow.org/2013/04/congressman-and-his-army-commander-reunite-during-aba-day-after-42-years|publisher=abanow.org|accessdate=August 9, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523045706/http://www.abanow.org/2013/04/congressman-and-his-army-commander-reunite-during-aba-day-after-42-years/|archivedate=May 23, 2013|df=mdy-all}} ==Local and state political career== After his military service, Frelinghuysen was hired by then-[[Morris County, New Jersey|Morris County]] [[Board of Chosen Freeholders|Freeholder]] Director [[Dean A. Gallo]] to be the county's state and federal aid coordinator and administrative assistant.{{cite web|title=Rodney P. Frelinghuysen (R)|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/elections/2004/candidates/22252|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201140203/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/elections/2004/candidates/22252|dead-url=yes|archive-date=February 1, 2014|work=Elections 2004|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=August 9, 2013}} He held this position until 1974, when he was elected as a Morris County Freeholder in his own right. He served three terms on the board, the last as its director.{{cite web|url=https://www.gop.gov/republicans/rodneyfrelinghuysen/bio|title=Rodney Frelinghuysen: Biography|publisher=GOP.gov|accessdate=August 29, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111062143/http://www.gop.gov/republicans/rodneyfrelinghuysen/bio|archivedate=November 11, 2013}} In 1983, Frelinghuysen was elected to the [[New Jersey General Assembly]], representing the [[New Jersey Legislative Districts, 2001 redistricting#District 25|25th legislative district]]. Frelinghuysen served in the Assembly until 1994. He was Chairman of the Assembly Appropriations Committee during the 1988–89 legislative session. In 1990 he ran in the Republican primary for New Jersey's 12th congressional district against [[Dick Zimmer (New Jersey politician)|Dick Zimmer]] and [[Phil McConkey]]. During the race, the Frelinghuysen campaign "broke ground in high-tech politicking" when it sent voters a seven-minute video cassette of Frelinghuysen. The video, which contained photographs of Frelinghuysen in Vietnam and praise from former Gov. [[Thomas Kean|Tom Kean]], served as a preemptive tactic against opponents' attempts to characterize Frelinghuysen as "an irrelevant debutante".{{cite web|last=Polman|first=Dick|title=Lights, Camera, Political Action: Campaigning In The Video Age|url=http://articles.philly.com/1990-04-26/news/25917767_1_political-video-congressional-candidates-video-age|newspaper=Philadelphia Inquirer|accessdate=August 9, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116072742/http://articles.philly.com/1990-04-26/news/25917767_1_political-video-congressional-candidates-video-age|archivedate=January 16, 2014|df=mdy-all}} Frelinghuysen finished in third place. ==U.S. House of Representatives== ===Elections=== In late August 1994, U.S. Congressman [[Dean Gallo]], the six-term Republican incumbent of [[New Jersey's 11th congressional district|New Jersey's Eleventh Congressional District]], announced his intention to withdraw from the upcoming election for medical reasons (he had recently been diagnosed with terminal [[prostate cancer]] and died two days before the election). As Gallo had already defeated three opponents in a hard-fought primary the previous June, his withdrawal triggered a convention of Republican committee members from the district's municipalities. Frelinghuysen, who had been Gallo's former employee and fellow Morris County freeholder and state assemblyman, sought the committee's nomination at Gallo's request, and was chosen to be the Republican nominee for the district.{{cite news|last=Sullivan|first=Joseph|title=Rep. Gallo Drops Out of Race, Citing Problems With Health|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/08/24/nyregion/rep-gallo-drops-out-of-race-citing-problems-with-health.html|accessdate=August 9, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=August 24, 1994}} Frelinghuysen went on to defeat former Democratic State Senator [[Frank Herbert (politician)|Frank Herbert]] 71% to 28% in the November 1994 election.{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=28952|title=NJ District 11 Race|date=November 8, 1994|publisher=Our Campaigns|accessdate=February 22, 2017}} However, the 11th had long been one of the most Republican districts in the Northeast, and Frelinghuysen had effectively clinched a seat in Congress by winning the Republican nomination. He was reelected nine times with no substantive opposition, never dropping below 59% of the vote. He has been challenged in the Republican primary three times: in 2008, 2010, and 2014. In 2008, he defeated Kate Erber in the June primary 87% to 13%.{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=351543|title=NJ District 11 - R Primary Race|date=June 3, 2008|publisher=Our Campaigns|accessdate=February 22, 2017}} In 2010, he defeated Richard Luzzi 76% to 24%.{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=643636|title=NJ District 11 - R Primary Race|date=June 8, 2010|publisher=Ourcampaigns.com|accessdate=February 22, 2017}} In 2014, he defeated Rick Van Glahn 67% to 33%.{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=800857|title=NJ District 11 - R Primary Race|date=June 3, 2014|publisher=Our Campaigns|accessdate=February 22, 2017}} On January 29, 2018 Frelinghuysen announced that he wouldn't run for another term in 2018. In 2000, progressive activist filmmaker [[Michael Moore]] attempted to have a [[ficus]] challenge Frelinghuysen's unopposed re-election to make the point that most Members of Congress "run unopposed in their primaries and 95% are re-elected every time in the general election", adding "we think it's time to point out to the Frelinghuysen family that we live in a democracy, not a dynasty."{{cite web|last=Moore |first=Michael |date=April 26, 2000 |url=http://www.commondreams.org/news2000/0426-09.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080119080414/http://www.commondreams.org/news2000/0426-09.htm|title=Ficus Plant Announces Candidacy For Congress |type=press release |work=[[Common Dreams]]: Progressive Newswire. ''commondreams.org'' |archivedate=January 19, 2008}} The top sectors supporting Frelinghuysen's campaigns have been the [[Aerospace manufacturer|aerospace]], [[Defense industry|defense]], [[pharmaceutical industry|pharmaceutical]] and [[health care industry|health care]] industries.VoteSmart, [https://votesmart.org/candidate/campaign-finance/22177/rodney-frelinghuysen#.WljPbCinHrc Rodney Frelinghuysen's Campaign Finances], Retrieved January 12, 2017, "...Top contributors: ... Lockheed Martin... Northrup Grumman ... Celgene Corporation ..." ===Committee assignments=== * '''[[United States House Committee on Appropriations|Committee on Appropriations]]''' (Chairman) **As chair of the full committee, Frelinghuysen may sit as an ''ex officio'' member of all subcommittees ===Coalitions and caucuses=== * [[Republican Main Street Partnership]] * [[Republican Majority For Choice]] * [[Republicans for Choice]] * [[Republicans For Environmental Protection]] ====Legislative record==== Since the start of his congressional tenure in 1995, Frelinghuysen has been the chief sponsor of 123 bills.{{citation needed|date=January 2018}} Of these, four have become law: * H.R. 1366 (104th): To authorize the extension of time limitation for the [[Federal Energy Regulatory Commission|FERC]]-issued hydroelectric license for the [[Mount Hope, New Jersey|Mount Hope]] Waterpower Project. * H.R. 459 (106th): To extend the deadline under the [[Federal Power Act]] for FERC Project No. 9401, the Mount Hope Waterpower Project. * H.R. 1964 (108th): [[Highland]]s Conservation Act * H.R. 4850 (108th): District of Columbia Appropriations Act, 2005 He has been the chief sponsor of nine [[Resolution (law)#Houses of legislature|resolutions]], none of which passed.{{cite web|title=Rep. Rodney Frelinghuysen|url=http://www.govtrack.us|publisher=govtrack.org|accessdate=July 8, 2013}}{{failed verification|date=January 2018}} He introduced an amendment to the [[Disaster Relief Appropriations Act, 2013]], the initial Hurricane Sandy relief legislation, which added $33.7 billion to the $17 billion initially allocated by the act. The amendment passed the House in a 228–192 vote, with the support of 38 Republicans and 190 Democrats.{{cite web|last=Kasperowicz|first=Pete|title=House accepts $33.7B Sandy bill amendment|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/floor-action/house/277359-house-accepts-337-billion-amendment-to-sandy-bill|work=The Hill's Floor Action Blog|publisher=The Hill|accessdate=February 23, 2017}} The amended act was not significantly modified by the Senate, and was signed into law. ==Political positions== As of January 2018, Frelinghuysen had voted with his party in 95.4% of votes so far in the [[115th United States Congress]] and voted in line with President Trump's position in 90.2% of the votes.{{Cite news|url=https://projects.propublica.org/represent/members/F000372-rodney-p-frelinghuysen|title=Represent|last=|first=|work=ProPublica|access-date=March 2, 2017}}{{Cite news|url=https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/congress-trump-score/rodney-p-frelinghuysen/|title=Tracking Rodney P. Frelinghuysen In The Age Of Trump|last=Bycoffe|first=Aaron|date=January 30, 2017|work=FiveThirtyEight|accessdate=March 2, 2017|language=en-US}} From the start of his tenure in the 104th Congress to the current 113th, Frelinghuysen has voted with his party 90% of the time.{{cite web|url=http://projects.washingtonpost.com/congress/113|title=US Congress Votes database|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=August 8, 2013}}{{failed verification|date=January 2018}} Frelinghuysen's voting record has been described as moderate.{{cite web|url=http://www.ontheissues.org/NJ/Rodney_Frelinghuysen.htm|title=OnTheIssues.org: Rodney Frelinghuysen|publisher=On The Issues|date=July 17, 2016|accessdate=March 3, 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://archive.northjersey.com/news/rep-rodney-frelinghuysen-says-he-s-voting-for-trump-1.1682678|title=Rep. Rodney Frelinghuysen says he's voting for Trump|date=October 25, 2016|accessdate=March 3, 2017|publisher=North Jersey Media Group|author=Herb Jackson}} He is a member of the [[Republican Main Street Partnership]].{{cite news|url=http://www.northjersey.com/news/173838591_Frelinghuysen_insists_he_s_a_moderate.html?page=all|title=Frelinghuysen insists he's a moderate|last=Linhorst|first=Michael|date=October 12, 2012|accessdate=August 9, 2013|newspaper=The Record, NorthJersey.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.prochoiceamerica.org/media/press-releases/2011/pr05062011_lance-frelinghuysen.html|title=False Moderates Lance, Frelinghuysen Advance the War on Women with Support of Extreme Anti-Choice H.R.3|publisher=NARAL Pro-Choice America|accessdate=August 9, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130721130230/http://www.prochoiceamerica.org/media/press-releases/2011/pr05062011_lance-frelinghuysen.html|archive-date=July 21, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} During the 2012 election season, Frelinghuysen rejected claims from [[Planned Parenthood]] leaders and progressive activists that he "toes the line of Republican leadership" and had aligned himself with the [[Tea Party movement]]. As Frelinghuysen is less conservative than many members of the Republican caucus, he was elevated to the Appropriations Committee chairship only based on his assurance to the conservatives that he would be willing to set aside his personal views to implement party policy. One conservative on the committee, Representative [[Robert Aderholt]], said, "One of the things we had discussed going into this, when he wanted to take the chairmanship, was that at the end of the day he understood that when he was negotiating these bills he'd be negotiating on behalf of his conference, as opposed to his own philosophy."{{cite web|url=http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/new-jersey/2017/04/06/report-gop-heat-frelinghuysen-over-health-insurance-opposition/100122902|title=Report: GOP heat on Frelinghuysen over health bill|last=Jackson|first=Herb|website=NorthJersey.com|publisher=[[North Jersey Media Group]]|accessdate=April 6, 2017}} In a tele-townhall on March 20, 2017, he stated that was "not sold" on attempts to repeal and replace the [[Affordable Care Act]] (also known as [[Obamacare]]) and had not seen any evidence to support claims that President Trump was wiretapped during the campaign. He believes Trump should release his tax returns, but does not support attempts to compel their release, adding "I need to support the Chair's ruling regardless of what the issue is."{{Cite web|url=https://morristowngreen.com/2017/03/20/rodney-frelinghuysen-not-sold-on-healthcare-bill-supports-nih-public-radio-trump-tweets-out-of-control|title=Rodney Frelinghuysen 'not sold' on healthcare bill, supports NIH, public radio; Trump tweets 'out of control'|last=Coughlin|first=Kevin|accessdate=March 22, 2017}} ===Abortion=== Frelinghuysen is a member of [[Republican Majority For Choice]] and [[Republicans for Choice]]. In 2017, he voted against the [[Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act]], which would have implemented a national ban on abortions performed after 20 weeks of gestation.{{cite news|last1=Kilgore|first1=Ed|title=House Passes 20-Week Abortion Ban on Near-Perfect Party-Line Vote|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2017/10/house-passes-20-week-abortion-ban-on-party-vote.html|accessdate=January 11, 2018|publisher=New York Magazine|date=October 3, 2017}} From 2010-12, his NARAL rating averaged 7%.{{cite web|url=https://votesmart.org/candidate/key-votes/22177/rodney-frelinghuysen#.WlgDF7j6jIY|title=The Voter's Self Defense System|website=Vote Smart}}{{failed verification|date=January 2018}} He and fellow [[New Jersey]] Republican [[Leonard Lance]] were singled out by [[NARAL]] President [[Nancy Keenan]] over their support of H.R. 3 "No Taxpayer Funding for Abortions Act". Frelinghuysen voted in 2015 to strip all federal funding from [[Planned Parenthood]], despite having opposed similar measures in 2011, 2009 and 2007. He cited the [[Planned Parenthood 2015 undercover videos controversy]] for his change in position.{{citation needed|date=January 2018}} ===Economy and budget=== In October 2017, Frelinghuysen was the only representative from New Jersey to vote in favor of a Republican budget resolution that would increase the federal deficit by $1.5 trillion. He said he voted "for the budget resolution to get my appropriations bills done" and that he would "evaluate tax reform when I see the details."{{Cite news|url=http://www.nj.com/politics/index.ssf/2017/10/your_property_tax_break_just_became_more_endangere.html|title=You're now more at risk of losing your property tax break|work=NJ.com|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en-US}} In December 2017, Frelinghuysen voted against the [[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017]].{{cite web|last1=Almukhtar|first1=Sarah|title=How Each House Member Voted on the Tax Bill|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/12/19/us/politics/tax-bill-house-live-vote.html?_r=0|website=The New York Times|accessdate=December 21, 2017|date=December 19, 2017}} Frelinghuysen is a supporter of [[Earmark (politics)|earmarking]], calling the practice a "constitutional responsibility."{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/rodney-frelinghuysen-r-nj/gIQAFP2pAP_topic.html|title=Who Runs Gov: Rodney Frelinghuysen (R-NJ) U.S. Representative (since January 1995)|date=December 22, 2011|accessdate=August 9, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post}}{{failed verification|date=January 2018}} He consistently ranks in the top 5% in terms of dollars procured. In fiscal year 2008 he ranked 21st, sponsoring or co-sponsoring 44 earmarks totaling $88 million; in fiscal year 2009 he ranked 12th, with 45 earmarks totaling $119 million; and in fiscal year 2010 he ranked 21st with 39 earmarks totaling $76 million. During the same period, Frelinghuysen was the top earmarker among New Jersey lawmakers. The majority of his earmarks were for defense-related expenses.{{cite web|url=http://www.opensecrets.org/politicians/earmarks.php?fy=FY10&cid=N00000684&cycle=2010|title=Rodney Frelinghuysen: Earmarks (Fiscal Year 2010)|publisher=The Center for Responsive Politics|accessdate=August 9, 2013}} ===Environment=== [[File:Rodney Frelinghuysen lifetime LCV scores.jpg|thumb|Annual [[League of Conservation Voters|LCV]] ratings for Rodney Frelinghuysen]] Frelinghuysen's environmental position, as measured by the [[League of Conservation Voters]] annual "Environmental National Scorecard", was largely centrist from 1995 to 2008, averaging 55%. Beginning in 2009, his environmental record veered sharply negative, averaging just 14% over the next nine years, through 2017. In 2017 Frelinghuysen was given a rating of 9%, the lowest of any New Jersey congressional representative. As of 2017, Frelinghuysen's lifetime LCV Scorecard score was 33%.{{cite web |url=http://scorecard.lcv.org/moc/rodney-p-frelinghuysen |title=Representative Rodney Frelinghuysen |work=National Environmental Scorecard |publisher=[[League of Conservation Voters]] |accessdate=March 19, 2018}} [[File:Rodney Frelinghuysen.jpg|thumb|left|Frelinghuysen tours a [[Superfund]] site in his district]] In May, 2003, Frelinghuysen introduced H.R. 1964, the [[Highlands Conservation Act]], a bill that recognized "the importance of the water, forest, agricultural, wildlife, recreational, and cultural resources of the [[New York–New Jersey Highlands|Highlands region]], and the national significance of the Highlands region to the United States", and authorized up to $10 million a year in federal matching funds for land preservation and protection in the Highlands states (Pennsylvania, New Jersey, New York, and Connecticut), as well as $1 million a year for [[United States Forest Service]] research and technical assistance programs. In November, 2004, [[George W. Bush]] signed the Highlands Conservation Act into law. In 2014, Congress failed to re-authorize the Act and the program expired.{{cite web |url=https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/108/hr1964|title=H.R. 1964 (108th): Highlands Conservation Act|publisher=Civic Impulse, LLC|accessdate=March 20, 2018}} As of May, 2014 Frelinghuysen was one of eight Republican members of Congress who "accept the prevailing scientific conclusion that global warming is both real and man-made," according to [[PolitiFact]].{{cite news|title=Jerry Brown says 'virtually no Republican' in Washington accepts climate change science|first=Julie|last=Kliegman|date=May 18, 2014|accessdate=September 28, 2017|work=[[PolitiFact]]|publisher=''[[Tampa Bay Times]]''|url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2014/may/18/jerry-brown/jerry-brown-says-virtually-no-republican-believes-}} However, he opposes federal regulation of greenhouse gas emissions.{{Cite web|url=http://votesmart.org/candidate/political-courage-test/22177/rodney-frelinghuysen/#.WLijFxKLSfQ|title=The Voter's Self Defense System|website=Project Vote Smart|accessdate=March 2, 2017}} The [[Sunlight Foundation]] pointed out that among the 435 members of the U.S. House of Representatives, Frelinghuysen has the third-highest amount of investment in [[Petroleum industry|oil]] stocks.{{cite web|url=https://sunlightfoundation.com/2008/08/08/oil-industry-influence-personal-finances/|title=The Sunlight Foundation Blog – Oil Industry Influence: Personal Finances'|publisher=Sunlight Foundation|accessdate=August 8, 2008}} {{clear left}} ===Health care=== He favors repealing the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]] (Obamacare), and voted in support of the budget resolution to repeal Obamacare in January 2017. In March 2017, when the Republican leadership was seeking support for the "repeal-and-replace" bill, the [[American Health Care Act of 2017|American Health Care Act]] (AHCA), he announced that he would oppose it on the grounds that it "would place significant new costs and barriers to care on my constituents in New Jersey" and would result in a "loss of [[Medicaid]] coverage for so many people in my Medicaid-dependent state."{{cite web|url=http://www.nj.com/politics/index.ssf/2017/05/frelinghuysen.html|title=N.J.'s Frelinghuysen changes stance and votes to repeal Obamacare|last=Salant|first=Jonathan D.|date=May 4, 2017|website=nj.com|publisher=[[Advance Digital]]|accessdate=May 12, 2017}} On May 4, 2017, he voted for a revised version of the AHCA,{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/politics/ahca-house-vote|title=How the House voted to pass the GOP health-care bill|website=Washington Post|accessdate=May 4, 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/05/04/politics/house-health-care-vote/index.html|title=How every member voted on health care bill|website=CNN|accessdate=May 4, 2017}} although the provisions he had previously cited as objectionable were unchanged. He said that he "voted for an improved health care act".{{Cite news|url=http://www.nj.com/morris/index.ssf/2017/05/frelinghuysen_in_latest_telephone_town_hall_defend.html|title=Frelinghuysen defends Obamacare repeal vote in telephone town hall|work=NJ.com|accessdate=May 11, 2017}} Frelinghuysen stressed the need to "protect those with pre-existing conditions", but according to NJ.com, the bill "would allow for exemptions from rules preventing those with pre-existing conditions from being charged more for their insurance. It also would allow states to request waivers from federal requirements that all insurers cover specific benefits such as hospitalization, mental health treatment and maternity care." Asked why he voted for the bill without waiting for an estimate from the Congressional Budget Office on its impact, Frelinghuysen said, "I think there was a feeling that we needed to act and get the bill to the Senate so we can get them to act on it." ===Immigration=== Frelinghuysen opposes [[Sanctuary city|sanctuary cities]]. As Chairman of the [[House Appropriations Committee]], he was part of the 29 representatives voting to send the 2018 Homeland Security appropriations bill to the full House. Among other funding, the bill includes $5 billion in funding for Trump's border wall. Referring to the bill, Frelinghuysen stated the bill "provides the necessary funding for critical technology and physical barriers to secure our borders".{{cite web |last1=Elis |first1=Niv |title=House panel advances homeland security bill with $5 billion in border wall funding |url=http://thehill.com/homenews/house/398881-house-panel-advances-homeland-security-bill-with-5-billion-in-border-wall |website=The Hill |accessdate=29 July 2018}} ===Donald Trump=== Frelinghuysen endorsed Donald Trump in the 2016 presidential election. ===Other issues=== Frelinghuysen is in favor of [[Federal Reserve Transparency Act|auditing the Federal Reserve]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.ontheissues.org/NJ/Rodney_Frelinghuysen.htm|title=Rodney Frelinghuysen on the Issues|last=OnTheIssues.org|website=www.ontheissues.org|access-date=March 2, 2017}} and supported the Iraq War. He opposes same-sex marriage, and has voted against legislation which would establish [[net neutrality]], which refers to the [[principle]] that [[Internet service provider]]s cannot discriminate by user, content, website, or platform, and has voted in favor of legislation that would [[Voter ID laws in the United States|require photo IDs]] for voting in federal elections. He has a "D" rating from [[NORML]] regarding his voting record on [[cannabis]]-related matters. He twice voted against providing veterans access to [[medical marijuana]] via their Veterans Health Administration doctor's recommendation.{{cite web|title=New Jersey Scorecard - NORML.org - Working to Reform Marijuana Laws|url=http://norml.org/congressional-scorecard/new-jersey|website=norml.org|accessdate=December 21, 2017}} He blocked a vote on an amendment that would have given banks the ability to lend to legal, state-regulated marijuana businesses without having to worry about subsequent punishment by federal financial regulators.{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/tomangell/2018/06/13/marijuana-banking-measure-rejected-by-congressional-committee/#1afed24e4208|title=Marijuana Banking Measure Rejected By Congressional Committee|last=Angell|first=Tom|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-06-18|language=en}} ==Town halls and criticism of activist== Frelinghuysen, who has not appeared at a public town hall since 2013, prefers small events at schools, community groups, and veteran organizations, according to ''[[The New York Times]]''. Since the 2016 election, a grassroots activist group called NJ 11th for Change has organized demonstrations and town halls in an effort to get a face-to-face between Frelinghuysen and his constituents.{{Cite web|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/why-republicans-should-be-scared-of-town-hall-protests|title=Why Republicans Should Be Scared of Town Hall Protests|website=Vice|accessdate=February 23, 2017}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.njherald.com/20170219/11th-district-protesters-want-face-to-face-with-frelinghuysen|title=11th District protesters want face-to-face with Frelinghuysen|newspaper=New Jersey Herald|accessdate=February 23, 2017}} In 2017, Frelinghuysen wrote a campaign fundraising letter to a board member of a local bank. While Frelinghuysen did not name NJ 11th for Change, a progressive lobbying group, he included a handwritten postscript warning "One of the ringleaders works in your bank!", with an attached news article about one of NJ 11th for Change's members. The individual subsequently resigned from her position as assistant general counsel and senior vice president at that bank, citing pressure over her political involvement as one of the reasons.{{Citation|title=Frelinghuysen Targets Activist in Letter to Her Employer|url=http://www.wnyc.org/story/frelinghuysen-targets-activsts-letter-boss|accessdate=May 15, 2017}} According to a lawyer and former staffer for the [[Office of Congressional Ethics]], to be unlawful such a letter would need to threaten action or be written on congressional stationery, not campaign letterhead, and/or the bank would have to have business pending before a Frelinghuysen committee.Nancy Solomon, [http://www.wnyc.org/story/frelinghuysen-targets-activsts-letter-boss Frelinghuysen Targets Activist in Letter to Her Employer], [[WNYC]], May 15, 2017.{{Cite news|url=http://theweek.com/speedreads/698945/gop-congressman-told-constituents-boss-that-opposed-trump-afraid-uncomfortable-resigned|title=A GOP congressman told a constituent's boss that she opposed Trump. Afraid and uncomfortable, she resigned.|accessdate=May 15, 2017}}{{Cite news|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/house/333395-gop-rep-goes-after-activist-by-writing-letter-to-employer|title=GOP rep goes after activist by writing letter to employer|last=Shelbourne|first=Mallory|work=TheHill|accessdate=May 15, 2017}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.nj.com/politics/index.ssf/2017/05/frelinghuysen_outed_anti-trump_activist_to_her_emp.html|title=Frelinghuysen outed anti-Trump activist to her employer|work=NJ.com|accessdate=May 15, 2017}} The progressive lobbying group [[Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington]] (CREW) opined that "whether or not [Frelinghuysen's letter] breaks a criminal statute is one issue, but the very clear issue is that it appears that a member of Congress might be using his power to threaten someone's employment because of their political activities." [[Richard Painter|Richard W. Painter]], a professor of law at the [[University of Minnesota]] and former chief White House ethics lawyer to President George W. Bush, described Frelinghuysen's actions as "not illegal but an awful thing to do."{{Cite web |url= http://www.nj.com/politics/index.ssf/2017/07/does_frelinghuysen_face_ethical_troubles_the_auditor.html |title= Does Frelinghuysen face ethical troubles? {{!}} The Auditor |website= NJ.com |accessdate= March 22, 2018}} Nonprofit ethics watchdog [[Campaign for Accountability]] filed a complaint with the [[Office of Congressional Ethics]] requesting an investigation into whether Frelinghuysen violated House ethics rules in his letter to the board member of the bank.{{cite news |last1= Caygle |first1=Heather |title= Frelinghuysen faces ethics complaint for targeting activist |url= https://www.politico.com/story/2017/05/16/rodney-frelinghuysen-ethics-complaint-238452 |accessdate= 12 January 2018 |publisher= Politico |date=May 16, 2017 }} Anyone can file a complaint with the Office of Congressional Ethics; the office reviews complaints from the public and can choose to refer those it considers valid to the House Ethics Committee.{{cite news |last1= Jackson |first1=Herb |title= Frelinghuysen hires lawyers after ethics complaint about 'ringleader' letter |url= https://www.northjersey.com/story/news/new-jersey/2017/07/13/frelinghuysen-taps-lawyers-after-ringleader-ethics-complaint/475077001/|accessdate=12 January 2018|publisher=NorthJersey.com|date=July 13, 2017}} Frelinghuysen hired lawyers following the complaint. ==Awards and honors== [[File:FrelinghuysenNavyMedal.jpg|thumb|right|Secretary of the Navy [[Ray Mabus]] speaks with U.S. Rep. Rodney Frelinghuysen before presenting him with the Navy Distinguished Public Service Medal, at the U.S. Capitol in 2013.]] In June 2013, Frelinghuysen was awarded the [[Navy Distinguished Public Service Award]], the Navy's highest civilian honor, for the "long and selfless service" he had provided to the force, ensuring it had necessary resources and supporting its members' quality of life.{{cite web|url=http://newjerseyhills.com/morris_news_bee/news/navy-s-highest-civilian-honor-goes-to-frelinghuysen/article_53e5d22a-d9e3-11e2-950d-001a4bcf887a.html|title=Navy's highest civilian honor goes to Frelinghuysen|last1=Garber|first1=Phil|date=June 21, 2013|accessdate=July 20, 2013}} Frelinghuysen was awarded the [[Vietnam Service Medal]] for his service during the [[Vietnam War]]. {{clear left}} ==Personal life== At the start of the 112th Congress, Frelinghuysen was ranked the ninth wealthiest member of congress, with an estimated personal wealth between $20 million and $65 million.{{cite web|title=Top 5 Political Heirs|last=Besnainou|first=David and Sarah Parnass|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/top-political-heirs/story?id=15047194|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=August 8, 2013}} A [[Roll Call|CQ Roll Call]] report on Frelinghuysen's wealth in 2010 indicated that about a third stemmed from personal and family trust investments in [[Procter & Gamble]] stock. He owns multiple properties, including nearly 18 acres of undeveloped land in [[Frelinghuysen Township, New Jersey|Frelinghuysen Township]], New Jersey.{{cite web|last=Toscano|first=Paul|title=The Richest Members of the US Congress 2011|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/44501966/device/xml/for/rawNO|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170224053933/https://www.cnbc.com/id/44501966/device/xml/for/rawNO|dead-url=yes|archive-date=February 24, 2017|publisher=CNBC|accessdate=August 9, 2013}} On May 24, 2007, Frelinghuysen chased down a pickpocket who had stolen his wallet near his home in the [[Georgetown, Washington, D.C.|Georgetown neighborhood]] of [[Washington, D.C.]] Two [[Metropolitan Police Department of the District of Columbia|Washington police officers]] saw the chase and arrested the 18-year-old suspect who had been caught by the 61-year-old congressman.{{cite news|title=Congressman chases down pickpocket|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/oddlyEnoughNews/idUSHUN58348920070525|publisher=Reuters|date=May 25, 2007|accessdate=February 23, 2017}} ==Electoral history== {| class="wikitable" style="margin:0.5em ; [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] |branch= [[United States Army]]
[[Union Army]] |serviceyears=1861–1864 |rank=[[File:Union army lt col rank insignia.jpg|35px]] [[Lieutenant Colonel (United States)|Lieutenant Colonel]]
[[File:Union Army brigadier general rank insignia.svg|35px]] [[Brevet (military)|Brevet]] [[Brigadier general (United States)|Brigadier General]] |commands= |unit= {{nowrap|[[6th Wisconsin Volunteer Infantry Regiment|6th Wisconsin Infantry Regiment]]}} |battles= [[American Civil War]] |awards= |laterwork= }} '''Rufus R. Dawes''' (July 4, 1838 – August 1, 1899) was a military officer in the [[Union Army]] during the [[American Civil War]]. He used the middle initial "R" but had no middle name. He was noted for his service in the famed [[Iron Brigade]], particularly during the [[Battle of Gettysburg]]. He was a post-war businessman, [[Congressman]], and [[author]], and the father of four nationally known sons, one of whom, [[Charles G. Dawes]], won the Nobel Peace Prize and served as [[Vice President of the United States]], and of two daughters. He was himself a great-grandson of [[William Dawes]], who alerted [[Thirteen Colonies|colonial]] [[Minutemen (militia)|minutemen]] of the approach of the [[British Army|British army]] prior to the [[Battles of Lexington and Concord]] at the outset of the [[American Revolution]], and a maternal great-grandson of the Rev. Manasseh Cutler, who was instrumental in adoption of the Northwest ordinance of 1787, led the formation of the Ohio Company of Associates, and became "Father of Ohio University". Ferris, Mary Walton. "Dawes - Gates Ancestral Lines, Vol. I and II", privately printed 1943. ==Civil War== Having migrated to [[Wisconsin]] prior to the outbreak of the Civil WarEicher, John H., and [[David J. Eicher]], ''Civil War High Commands.'' Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2001. {{ISBN|0-8047-3641-3}}. p. 204., Dawes organized a volunteer company from Juneau County in May, was elected Captain and appointed as such by the State on May 5, and on July 16, 1861, his Company K was mustered into the 6th Wisconsin Volunteer Infantry for three years service. The regiment served for almost a year in Northern Virginia without seeing major action. In June, 1862, Dawes was promoted to [[Major (United States)|major]]. He served with his [[regiment]] at the [[Second Battle of Manassas|Battle of Groveton]] and at [[Battle of Antietam|Antietam]] and [[Battle of Fredericksburg|Fredericksburg]]. In March, 1863, Dawes received a promotion to the rank of [[Lieutenant colonel (United States)|lieutenant colonel]] and served in the [[Battle of Chancellorsville|Chancellorsville Campaign]], leading a river crossing under fire at Fitzhugh's Crossing on April 29.Magnusen, Steve. "To My Best Girl", Indianapolis, IN, Dog Ear Publishing, LLC, 2018 ({{ISBN|978-1-4575-6431-4}}) pp. 76-85, 88-124, and 234-239. During the [[Battle of Gettysburg, First Day|first day of the Battle of Gettysburg]] on July 1, 1863, Dawes led a [[counterattack]] on [[Confederate States Army|Confederate]] [[Brigadier General (CSA)|Brigadier General]] [[Joseph R. Davis|Joseph R. Davis's]] [[brigade]] of the 2nd, 11th and 42nd Mississippi Infantry Regiments and the 55th North Carolina Infantry Regiment, many of whom were sheltered in an unfinished railroad cut west of town, and forced the surrender of more than 200 of the Confederate soldiers. He later served that year in the [[Mine Run Campaign]]. During a furlough, Dawes returned to Ohio and married Mary Beman Gates (1842–1921), from Marietta, Ohio, on January 18, 1864. Returning to the [[Army of the Potomac]], he served at the [[Battle of the Wilderness]] and the [[Siege of Petersburg]] In July 1864, Dawes was offered the full rank of [[Colonel (United States)|colonel]], but declined the promotion. He was mustered out of the army on August 10, 1864, following the Battles of [[Battle of Spotsylvania|Spotsylvania]] and [[Battle of Cold Harbor|Cold Harbor]]. On February 24, 1866, [[President of the United States|President]] [[Andrew Johnson]] nominated Dawes for appointment to the grade of [[Brevet (military)|brevet]] [[Brigadier general (United States)|brigadier general]] of volunteers to rank from March 13, 1865, and the [[United States Senate]] confirmed the appointment on April 10, 1866.Eicher, 2001, p. 743.Hunt, Roger D. and Jack R. Brown, ''Brevet Brigadier Generals in Blue.'' Gaithersburg, MD: Olde Soldier Books, Inc., 1990. {{ISBN|1-56013-002-4}}. p. 151. After the war, Dawes became a Companion of the Ohio Commandery of the [[Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States]]. Some of Dawes' letters are available to researchers.[http://www.nps.gov/archive/gett/getttour/sidebar/dawes.htm] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100203090504/http://www.nps.gov/archive/gett/getttour/sidebar/dawes.htm |date=February 3, 2010 }} From his time in the Civil War, Dawes likely suffered from [[post-traumatic stress disorder]], although he was able to cope with the symptoms.Reid, John J. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Zgg6c_Ndtu4C&pg=PA423 'Crisis of the Ottoman Empire: Prelude to Collapse, 1838–1878']. Stuttgart: F. Steiner, 2000. {{ISBN|978-3-515-07687-6}}. Retrieved July 12, 2012. p. 423. ==Postbellum career== Dawes returned home to Marietta, Ohio and entered the lumber business. In August of that year, his son [[Charles Gates Dawes]] was born, a future [[Vice President of the United States]]. In July 1867, [[Rufus C. Dawes]] was born at the family home. He would become a well-respected businessman and lawyer, being awarded [[Chicago]]'s Most Distinguished Citizen Award" in 1934. A third son, [[Beman Gates Dawes]], would later serve as a Congressman from Ohio, and [[Henry May Dawes]] would be a powerful banker who would serve as [[Office of the Comptroller of the Currency|Comptroller of the Currency]] for the United States under [[Warren G. Harding]] and [[Calvin Coolidge]]. Rufus and Mary Dawes also had two daughters, Mary Frances Dawes Beach and Betsey Dawes Hoyt. Dawes also served on the Board of Trustees of Marietta College from 1871 until his death, 28 years later. He was also a [[Trustee]] for Ohio's Institute for the Deaf and Dumb. Dawes was elected to the [[U.S. House of Representatives]] in 1881 as a representative from the 15th Congressional District. A [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]], he served for one term before losing his bid for re-election because he voted against the [[Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882]]Sortland, R. A. (1958). ''Charles G. Dawes: Businessman in Politics.'' Unpublished manuscript, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, OH. p. 4. In 1890, he published a well-received account of his Civil War career, ''Service with the 6th Wisconsin Volunteers.'' This memoir was republished in Madison, Wisconsin by the [[Wisconsin Historical Society|State Historical Society of Wisconsin]] for the Wisconsin Civil War Centennial Commission, in 1962. His reputation as an orator and his influential voice for the establishment of diplomatic relations with [[Persia]] prompted President [[William McKinley]] to offer Dawes the position of Minister to Persia in 1897, a post he declined due to failing health. Dawes died two years later, August 1, 1899, in [[Marietta, Ohio]] and was buried in Oak Grove Cemetery, Marietta. Dawes was elected to Marietta College's Hall of Honor in 2003. ==See also== {{Portal|United States Army|American Civil War}} *[[List of American Civil War brevet generals (Union)]] *[[Ephraim C. Dawes]], younger brother of Rufus, a major who served under [[Ulysses S. Grant]] and [[William T. Sherman]] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== * Dawes, Rufus R. ''A Full Blown Yankee of the Iron Brigade: Service with the Sixth Wisconsin Volunteers''. Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, 1999. {{ISBN|0-8032-6618-9}}. First published 1890 by E. R. Alderman and Sons. * {{cite book |last=Dawes |first=Rufus Robinson |title=Service with the Sixth Wisconsin Volunteers {original publication} |authorlink= |publisher=Marietta, Ohio : E.R. Alderman & Sons |year=1890 |isbn= |url=https://archive.org/details/servsixthwiscon00dawerich |ref=dawes90}} * Eicher, John H., and [[David J. Eicher]], ''Civil War High Commands.'' Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2001. {{ISBN|0-8047-3641-3}}. * Herdegen, Lance J., ''"Those Damned Black Hats!" The Iron Brigade in the Gettysburg Campaign'', Savas Beatie LLC, October 2008. http://www.savasbeatie.com * Hunt, Roger D. and Jack R. Brown, ''Brevet Brigadier Generals in Blue.'' Gaithersburg, MD: Olde Soldier Books, Inc., 1990. {{ISBN|1-56013-002-4}}. * [http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=D000149 Congressional Biography] * Reid, John J. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Zgg6c_Ndtu4C&pg=PA423 'Crisis of the Ottoman Empire: Prelude to Collapse, 1838–1878']. Stuttgart: F. Steiner, 2000. {{ISBN|978-3-515-07687-6}}. Retrieved July 12, 2012 * Sortland, R. A. (1958). ''Charles G. Dawes: Businessman in Politics.'' Unpublished manuscript, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, OH. * University of Southern Mississippi, McCain Library and Archives - Dawes letter collection * Dawes Arboretum Archives, Newark, Ohio * Magnusen, Steve. "To My Best Girl -Courage, Honor and Love in the Civil War: The Inspiring Life Stories of Rufus Dawes and Mary Gates", Dog Ear Publishing, LLC, May 2018. http://www.stevemagnusen.com ==External links== *[http://www.wisconsinhistory.org/Content.aspx?dsNav=Ro:10,N:4294963828-4294963805&dsNavOnly=N:1104&dsRecordDetails=R:CS2572 Dawes, Col. Rufus R. (1838-1899) | Wisconsin Historical Society] *{{Find a Grave|5848728}} {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{succession box | before=[[George W. Geddes]] | title=[[List of United States Representatives from Ohio|U.S. Representative from Ohio's 15th Congressional District]] | years=1881–1883 | after=[[Adoniram J. Warner]]}} {{s-end}} {{OhioRepresentatives15}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dawes, Rufus R.}} [[Category:1838 births]] [[Category:1899 deaths]] [[Category:Ohio Republicans]] [[Category:People from Malta, Ohio]] [[Category:Union Army officers]] [[Category:Members of the United States House of Representatives from Ohio]] [[Category:People of Wisconsin in the American Civil War]] [[Category:Iron Brigade]] [[Category:Marietta College alumni]] [[Category:Dawes family]] [[Category:Politicians from Marietta, Ohio]] [[Category:Republican Party members of the United States House of Representatives]] [[Category:19th-century American politicians]] [[Category:Writers from Ohio]]

{{One source|date=April 2018}} The '''Sarabhai family''' is a major business family of [[India]] belonging to the [[Shrimal Jain]] community.<ref name="outlook">{{cite news|title=Vikram A Sarabhai|url=https://www.outlookindia.com/magazine/story/vikram-a-sarabhai/216858|accessdate=21 March 2018|publisher=Outlook|date=19 August 2002}}</ref>
Its eighteenth century doyen Sheth Ambalal Sarabhai, was a [[Gujarati people|Gujarati]] industrialist. He had five daughters and three sons who were involved in the family business as well as the Indian independence movement. After india's freedom, the family remained involved in developmental tasks undertaken by the government of India.
==Family members==
[[Ambalal Sarabhai]] was a prominent mill-owner and also interested in philanthropic activities. His wife Sarladevi Sarabhai was impressed by the [[Maria Montessori]] philosophy and in the year 1922, Montessori sent E. M. Standing to India for the [[homeschooling]] of Sarabhai children.
Sarabhai Enterprises branched out after India's independence and many pioneer ventures were made in fields dominated by foreign companies. The manufacture of drugs and pharmaceuticals, chemicals and intermediates, dyes and pigments, industrial and house hold detergents, soaps and cosmetics, industrial packaging and containers, and later engineering and electronic products.
Prominent members of the Sarabhai family include:
*[[Ambalal Sarabhai]] was in the 1940s and 1950s, the owner of the Sarabhai Textile Mills in [[Ahmedabad]] - at the time one of India's largest textile companies. **[[Anasuya Sarabhai]] (his sister), Gandhian freedom fighter **[[Surhid Sarabhai Sr]] (his son), industrialist ***[[Surhid Sarabhai Jr]] (Son of Surhid Sr) ***Sanjay Sarabhai **[[Gautam Sarabhai]] (his son), industrialist and philanthropist ***Mala & Shyama **[[Mridula Sarabhai]] (his daughter), freedom fighter and Indian politician ***Unmarried **[[Vikram Sarabhai]] (his son), co-founder of the [[Indian Space Research Organisation]] and [[Indian Institute of Management Ahmedabad]]. ***[[Mrinalini Sarabhai]] (Wife of Vikram Sarabhai), noted danseuse ***[[Kartikeya Sarabhai]] (his grandson), noted educationist and environmentalist ***[[Mallika Sarabhai]] (his granddaughter), noted danseuse and activist ****[[Revanta Sarabhai]] (dancer) **[[Leena Sarabhai]] (his daughter, founder of Shreyas Foundation) ***Married to Madanmohan Mangaldas Girdhardas, noted industrialist ***[[Kamal Mangaldas]] (her son, noted architect) **[[Gira Sarabhai]] (his daughter) ***Unmarried **[[Gita Mayor]] (his daughter) **[[Bharti Sarabhai]] (his daughter) ***Unmarried
==Institutions built by Sarabhai family==
# [[Calico Mills]] - Ambalal Sarabhai # [[Jubilee Mills]] - Ambalal Sarabhai # [[Jyoti Sangh]] - Mridulaben Sarabhai # [[Vikas Gruh]] - Mridulaben Sarabhai # [[Majoor Mahajan]] - Anasuyaben Sarabhai # [[Kasturba Gandhi Rashtriya Smarak Trust]] - Sarladevi Sarabhai # [[Shreyas Foundation & School]] - Leenaben Sarabhai # [[B.M. Institute of Mental Health]] - Gautam Sarabhai & Kamlini Sarabhai # The Physcotherapy Study Group - Gautam Sarabhai # [[National Institute of Design]] - Gautam Sarabhai & Giraben # [[Darpana Academy of Performing Arts]] - Mrinalini & Vikram Sarabhai # [[Calico Museum of Textiles]] - Giraben Sarabhai # [[Ambalal Sarabhai Enterprises, Baroda]] - Gautam Sarabhai # [[Centre for Environment Education]] - Kartikeya Sarabhai # [[Nehru Foundation for Development#Vikram Sarabhai Centre for Development Interaction .28VIKSAT.29|VIKSAT]] - Kartikeya Sarabhai # [[Nehru Foundation for Development#Centre for Health Education.2C Training and Nutrition Awareness .28CHETNA.29|CHETNA]] - Kartikeya Sarabhai # [[Sangeet Kendra]] - Geeta Mayor # [[Darpana for Development]] - Mallika Sarabhai # [[Mapin Publishing]] - Mallika Sarabhai & Bipin Shah
==Major Institution Building Efforts of Vikram Sarabhai (1947-1971)==
{{columns-list|colwidth=30em| # [[Ahmedabad Textile Industry’s Research Association]] (ATIRA) # [[Physical Research Laboratory]] (PRL), Ahmedabad # [[Indian Institute of Management]], Ahmedabad # [[Community Science Centre]] (CSC), Ahmedabad # [[Nehru Foundation for Development]] (NFD), Ahmedabad # [[Ahmedabad Management Association]] (AMA), Ahmedabad # [[Sarabhai Chemicals]], Baroda # [[Sarabhai Glass]], Baroda # [[Suhrid Geigy]], Baroda # [[Synbiotics]], Baroda # [[Sarabhai Merck]], Baroda # [[Sarabhai Engineering Group]], Baroda # [[Operations Research Group]] (ORG), Baroda # [[Sarabhai Research Centre]] (SRC), Baroda # [[Systronics]], Ahmedabad # [[Swastik Oil Mills]], Bombay # [[Standard Pharmaceuticals]], Calcutta # [[Thumba Equatorial Rocket Launching Station]] (TERLS), Trivandrum # [[Space Science and Technology Centre]] (SSTC), Trivandrum # [[Shriharikota Rocket Range]] (SHAR), Sriharikota # [[Experimental Satellite Communication Earth Station]] (ESCES), Ahmedabad # [[Satellite Communication System Division]] (SCSD), Ahmedabad # [[Electronics System Division]] (ESD), Ahmedabad # [[Microwave Antenna Systems Engineering Group]] (MASEG), Ahmedabad # [[Audio Visual Instructional Division]] (AVID), Ahmedabad # [[Remote Sensing and Meteorological Division]] (RSMD), Ahmedabad # [[Indian Scientific Satellite Project]] (ISSP), Bangalore # [[Satellite Instructional Television Experiment]] (SITE), Ahmedabad # [[Indian National Satellite]] (INSAT) Satellite Launching Vehicle (SLV) Trivandrum # [[Satellite Communication Earth Station]], # [[Arvi Fast Breeder Reactors]] (FBR), Kalpakkam # [[Nuclear Centre for Agriculture]], New Delhi # [[Variable Energy Cyclotron Project]] (VECP), Calcutta # [[Electronic Prototype Engineering Laboratory]] (EPEL), Bombay # [[Electronics Corporation of India]] (ECIL), Hyderabad # [[Uranium Corporation of India]] (UCIL), Jaduguda, Bihar }}
No.4 was renamed as the Vikram A. Sarabhai Community Science Centre after Dr. Sarabhai’s death in 1971. No.18 & 19 were merged under the Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre after Dr. Sarabhai’s death in 1971. Nos.21,22,23,24,25 and 26 were merged under the Space Applications Centre after Dr. Sarabhai’s death in 1971. No. 31 was renamed as Vikram Earth Station after Dr. Sarabhai’s death in 1971.
==See also== *[[Anusyabehn Sarabhai]] *[[Jainism]] *[[Swaminathan family]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.montessori-india.org/montessori_india.php Maria Montessory In India]

{{use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} {{use Indian English|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox legislation | short_title = Securities Laws (Amendment) Bill, 2014 | imagesize = 150 | long_title = An Act further to amend the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992, the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 and the Depositories Act, 1996 | citation = [http://www.finmin.nic.in/law/The%20Securities%20Laws%20Amendment%20Act%202014.pdf Act No. 27 of 2014] | territorial_extent = Whole of [[India]] | enacted_by = [[Parliament of India]] | date_assented = 22 August 2014 | date_commenced = 25 August 2014 | status = in force }} '''Securities Laws (Amendment) Act, 2014''' is a legislation in [[India]] which provided the [[securities]] market regulator [[Securities and Exchange Board of India]] (SEBI) with new powers to effectively pursue fraudulent investment schemes, especially [[ponzi scheme]]s.<ref name=sebi-teeth>{{cite news|title=Ponzi menace: Lok Sabha clears bill, Sebi gets more teeth|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/business-news/ponzi-menace-lok-sabha-clears-bill-sebi-gets-more-teeth/article1-1249098.aspx|accessdate=8 August 2014|work=[[Hindustan Times]]|date=7 August 2014}}</ref> The bill also provides guidelines for the formation of special fast trial courts.<ref name=empowerSEBI>{{cite news|title=Bill to empower Sebi introduced in LS|url=http://www.thestatesman.net/news/69653-bill-to-empower-sebi-introduced-in-ls.html|accessdate=8 August 2014|work=[[The Statesman (India)|The Statesman]]|agency=Press Trust of India|date=4 August 2014}}</ref>
==History== After the [[Saradha Group financial scandal]], the Government of India formed an inter-ministerial group to find ways to close off loopholes the regulations which allowed such [[pyramid scheme]]s to operate.<ref name=saradha>{{cite news|title=Presidential ordinance grants Sebi more powers|url=http://www.livemint.com/Politics/rEoGCnR4vSgamkiasujmMP/Presidential-ordinance-grants-Sebi-more-powers.html|accessdate=9 August 2014|work=[[Live Mint]]|date=18 July 2013}}</ref> The Securities Law (Amendment) Ordinance was promulgated on 17 July 2013, then for a second time in September 2013. It lapsed on 15 January 2014.<ref name=ordinance>{{cite news|title=Cabinet likely to consider proposal for Sebi ordinance today|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/business/companies/cabinet-likely-to-consider-proposal-for-sebi-ordinance-today/|accessdate=8 August 2014|work=[[The Indian Express]]|date=28 February 2014}}</ref><ref name=third-time>{{cite news|title=Power to Sebi: Ordinance promulgated for third time|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/business/business-others/power-to-sebi-ordinance-promulgated-for-third-time/|accessdate=8 August 2014|work=[[The Indian Express]]|date=28 March 2014}}</ref> The bill couldn't be presented in the winter session of Parliament as the standing committee on finance had not finalized the report. It promulgated for a third time on 28 March 2014.<ref name=third-time/>
On 24 July 2014, [[National e-Governance Plan#Cabinet Committee on Economic Affairs .28CCEA.29|Cabinet Committee on Economic Affairs]] (CCEA) approved the bill.<ref name=cabinet-clears>{{cite news|title=Cabinet clears bill to empower Sebi to deal with ponzi schemes|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/business/business-others/cabinet-clears-bill-to-empower-sebi-to-deal-with-ponzi-schemes/|accessdate=8 August 2014|work=[[The Indian Express]]|date=24 July 2014}}</ref> The bill was introduced by [[Minister of State]] for Finance [[Nirmala Sitharaman]] in the [[Lok Sabha]] on 4 August 2014. She also introduced bills to amend Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 and [[Depositories Act]], 1996. The bills were introduced in the name of [[Finance Minister]] [[Arun Jaitley]], but he himself was unable to attend the house.<ref name=empowerSEBI/> The bill was passed by the Lok Sabha on 6 August 2014.<ref name=sebi-teeth/>
==Summary== The ordinance passed in March 2014 had 30 clauses, whereas the bill contained 57 clauses. The bill amended three pre-existing market related laws. It retained the powers given to SEBI in the ordinance, but also introduced safeguards against misuse.<ref name=tweaks>{{cite news|title=New Sebi bill tweaks provisions for penalties, seizures|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2014-08-04/news/52428345_1_new-sebi-rs-10-lakh-greater-powers|accessdate=9 August 2014|work=[[The Economic Times]]|date=4 Aug 2014}}</ref>
The new law gave SEBI the power to search and obtain information, including call records,<ref name=tweaks/> about any suspected entity from within or outside the firm. However, before conducting such searches SEBI must obtain a warrant from a [[Mumbai]] court.<ref name=tackle>{{cite news|title=Lok Sabha passes Bill to give teeth to Sebi to tackle ponzi menace|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2014-08-06/news/52514591_1_ponzi-menace-such-ponzi-schemes-fraudulent-investment-schemes|accessdate=8 August 2014|work=[[The Economic Times]]|date=6 August 2014}}</ref> Any unregistered scheme with a capital of more than a {{currency|100|INR}} [[crore]] was deemed as a [[collective investment scheme]], allowing SEBI to regulate it.<ref name=empowerSEBI/> Under pre-existing regulations, all collective investment schemes had to register with SEBI. However, many came to SEBI's attention only after complaints from defrauded investors.<ref name=sebi-teeth/>
Depending on the nature of the crime, minimum penalties may range from {{currency|1|INR}} [[lakh]] to {{currency|10|INR}} lakh. The minimum penalty for securities related crimes was set at {{currency|1|INR}} lakh. The minimum penalty for [[insider trading]] was at {{currency|10|INR}} lakh. The maximum penalty for [[insider trading]] was set at {{currency|25|INR}} crore or three times the profit, whichever was higher. SEBI was given the authority to initiate recovery and sale of assets. SEBI has also been given the power to enhance a penalty or settle an ongoing legal proceeding. Guidelines for special courts were also included in the bill.<ref name=tweaks/>
==See also== * [[Saradha Group financial scandal]] * [[Securities and Exchange Board of India (Alternative Investment Funds) Regulations, 2012]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Indian legislations}}
[[Category:Securities and Exchange Board of India]] [[Category:Indian business law]] [[Category:Acts of the Parliament of India 2014]] [[Category:2014 in Indian economy]] [[Category:Modi administration]] [[Category:Securities (finance)]]

{{Infobox video game | width = | title = | collapsible = | state = | image = Ski Park Manager.jpg | caption = | developer = [[Lankhor]] | publisher = [[Microïds]] | series = | engine = | released = 2002 | genre = | modes = | platforms = Windows PC }}
'''''Ski Park Manager''''' is a video game released in 2002, developed by [[Lankhor]] and published by [[Microïds]].
The game has 42 challenges and three levels of difficulty. The game has a career mode, where you buy and sell your ski resorts, to acquire the most popular ones. There is a training module, to learn the techniques of the game. This is a large variety of scenarios, including bankruptcy, school holidays, snowstorms, accidents, avalanches and low snowfall.
To entertain your holiday makers, the game has a large number of possible activities. Some of these are downhill and cross-country skiing, sledding, walking and shopping. You must construct your own infrastructure including chalets, hotels, apartments, facilities, shops, restaurants and bars. The landscape can be modified, for example by deforesting. And also allows players to develop and research new buildings in the Ski Lab plus building.
== External links == * [http://www.microids.com/en/catalogue/29/ski-park-manager-val-d-isere.html ''Ski Park Manager''] at [[Microïds]]
